Mean number (+/- SD) of oral bacterial species in SF were 14.0 (6.8) in the RA (p = 0.001) and 19.4 (7.1) in the PsA group (p < 0.001) compared to 4.0 (1.7) in controls. P. gingivalis, Tannerella forsythensis and @gm$ Prevotella intermedia @/gm$ were exclusively identified in RA and PsA SF.

@di$ Periodontitis @/di$ is a bacterial-induced inflammatory disease where teeth progressively lose their supporting tissues. Several population-based studies have shown increased incidence of @di$ periodontitis @/di$ with age starting from 35 years-old with high potential over the age of 65. We hypothesized that the presence of periodontopathic bacteria may affect AAA. We assumed that the infectious factor may increase the local inflammation and consequently the tissue degradation and also the healing process in our model. Therefore we have analysed thoroughly four main @di$ periodontal pathogens @/di$ (Porphyromonas gingivalis (Pg), @gm$ Treponema denticola @/gm$ (@gm$ Td @/gm$), Tannerella forsythia (Tf) and Prevotella intermedia (Pi) belonging to the red and orange complexes (Socransky et al.).

@di$ Periodontitis @/di$ is a polymicrobial chronic inflammatory disease of tooth-supporting tissues with bacterial etiology affecting all age groups, becoming chronic in a subgroup of older individuals. Periodontal pathogens Porphyromonas gingivalis, Tannerella forsythia, and @gm$ Treponema denticola @/gm$ are implicated in the development of a number of inflammatory pathologies at remote organ sites, including Alzheimer's disease (AD).

@di$ Protein and energy malnutrition @/di$, anemia, being very young and climatic factors (harmattan and rainy seasons) were identified as major risk factors. The three main bacteria identified were Staphylococcus aureus (21 cases), @gm$ Streptococcus pneumoniae @/gm$ (19 cases) and Haemophilus influenzae (6 cases).

@di$ Smoking @/di$ and drinking are the two famous living habits for GC risk, and bile reflux and inflammatory activity are the two pathologic factors driving the progression of nCAG to CAG/GC. Several studies proved that @di$ smoking @/di$ and drinking could alter the gastrointestinal microbiota. found that smoking distinctly altered the duodenal microbiota, but quitters and non-smokers occupied similar duodenal microbiota, suggesting that living habits-induced microbial alteration is plastic and reversible. found that the exposure of cigarette @di$ smoking @/di$ could increase the incidence of colorectal cancer in mice, accompanied with the absence of gut Parabacteroides distasonis and Lactobacillus spp., and the increased Eggerthella lenta was positively related to the fecal taurine deoxycholic acid (TDCA), which could in turn activate the intestinal epithelial MAPK/ERK pathway. Meanwhile, cigarette @di$ smoking @/di$ could reduce the expressive levels of intestinal mucosal junction protein-3 and ZO-1, but increase the serum LPS level, leading to intestinal barrier damage and colorectal cancer. found that the occurrence of alcoholic fatty liver was associated with altered gut microbiota, while found that the long-chain saturated fatty acids (palmitic acid, stearic acid) in Jinhua ham could prevent chronic alcohol-associated liver damage (ALD), and the preventive effect was associated with increased gut Akkermansia muciniphila and Lactobacillus. found that @gm$ Bacteroides xylanisolvens @/gm$ could degrade the cumulative nicotine in the intestine, and prevent the development of nonalcoholic fatty liver disease (NAFLD). However, the relationship between @di$ smoking @/di$/drinking and gastric microbiota is still unclear in the occurrence of CAG.

@di$ Stroke @/di$ (@di$ ST @/di$), endangering human health due to its high incidence and high mortality, is a global public health problem. There is increasing evidence that there is a link between the gut microbiota (GM) and neuropsychiatric diseases. We aimed to find the GM of @di$ ST @/di$, post-@di$ ST @/di$ cognitive impairment (PSCI), and post-@di$ ST @/di$ affective disorder (PSTD). GM composition was analyzed, followed by GM identification. Alpha diversity estimation showed microbiota diversity in @di$ ST @/di$ patients. Beta diversity analysis showed that the bacterial community structure segregated differently between different groups. At the genus level, @di$ ST @/di$ patients had a significantly higher proportion of @gm$ Enterococcus @/gm$ and lower content of Bacteroides, Escherichia-Shigella, and Megamonas. PSCI patients had a significantly higher content of @gm$ Enterococcus @/gm$, Bacteroides, and Escherichia-Shigella and a lower proportion of Faecalibacterium compared with patients with @di$ ST @/di$. Patients with PSTD had a significantly higher content of Bacteroides and Escherichia-Shigella and lower content of @gm$ Enterococcus @/gm$ and Faecalibacterium. Parabacteroides and Lachnospiraceae were associated with Montreal cognitive assessment score of @di$ ST @/di$ patients.

@di$ Urinary tract infection @/di$ (@di$ UTI @/di$) is one of the most common infectious diseases worldwide. It is more prevalent among females with an incidence rate 50-fold higher among the 20-50 years age group. There are various clinical manifestations of @di$ UTI @/di$ such as cystitis, pyelonephritis, asymptomatic bacteriuria, chronic and recurrent UTIs; of which cystitis is the most frequent presentation affecting the urinary bladder. The bacteria may further ascend in the urinary tract causing infection of the kidney; if timely management is not done. Majority cases of uncomplicated @di$ UTI @/di$ are community-acquired in origin and caused by uropathogenic   E. coli   (UPEC) and   Klebsiella   spp., constituting approximately 75-95 % of the total cases. The other less prevalent organisms are   Proteus   spp.,   Enterobacter   spp.,   Pseudomonas   spp.,   @gm$ Enterococcus faecalis @/gm$  ,   Staphylococcus saprophyticus   and   Staphylococcus aureus  . Diagnosis is made based on the presenting symptoms and significant bacteriuria, i.e. >=105 colony forming units of organism on culture. The outcome of @di$ UTI @/di$ may also depend upon the presence of underlying host factors such as age, diabetes, spinal cord injury and urinary catheterization among various others.
@di$ Vaginitis @/di$ Plus NuSwab  (LabCorp, NC, USA) is a semi-quantitative PCR analysis of the three most predictive marker organisms in BV, A. vaginae, @gm$ BVAB-2 @/gm$, and Megasphaera-1.

@di$ X- @/di$linked CGD results from mutations in the cytochrome b-245 heavy chain catalytic subunit (also known as gp91phox or NOX2 and coded by CYBB), and accounts for approximately 70% of CGD cases, The most common form of autosomal recessive CGD results from mutations in the regulatory protein NCF1 (coded by NCF1 and also known as p47phox), and accounts for 20% of CGD cases. Knocking out Cybb or Ncf1 (the latter referred to as Ncf1-/-) generated mouse models of CGD that showed increased susceptibility to bacterial and fungal infections compared to wild type (wt) mice. Spontaneous bacterial and fungal infections occurred in Ncf1-/- mice, with soft tissue infections by @gm$ Staphylococcus xylosus @/gm$ being the most common.

@di$ capsici infection @/di$ defined the chemical space of major classes of reprogrammed metabolites as comprising of phenylpropanoids, benzoic acids, glycoalkaloids, flavonoids, amino acids, organic acids and fatty acids. In the present study, untargeted and targeted metabolomics approaches based on ultra-high performance liquid chromatography coupled to mass spectrometric detection (UHPLC-MS) were combined to study the inducible metabolic responses of tomato plants (pre-primed with @gm$ Pseudomonas fluorescens @/gm$ N04 and Paenibacillus alvei T22) and subsequently challenged with Ph.

@gm$ A. johnsonii @/gm$ is known to be a member of the skin flora. @gm$ A. johnsonii @/gm$, the species associated with an increased RAS risk, has been isolated from clinical samples in association with bacteremia. R. gnavus is a member of the gut flora. Interestingly, an increase in R. gnavus in the gut flora is associated with Crohn's disease. In the salivary microbiota of RAS patients, the decrease in S. salivarius and the increase in Capnocytophaga sputigena were common to the changes observed in the mucosal microbiota. Capnocytophaga is normally found in the oral cavity but considered as an opportunistic pathogen involved in various infections, including endodontic infections, @di$ emphysema @/di$, and bacteremia. Collectively, these results indicate decreases in the members of healthy core microbiota but increases in rare species in the mucosal and salivary microbiota of RAS patients. Particularly, a decrease in S. salivarius and an increase in @gm$ A. johnsonii @/gm$ in the mucosa were associated with increased RAS risk.

@gm$ A. sobria @/gm$ extracellularly produces various virulence factors such as cytolysins, enterotoxins, and proteases. It is thought that these factors act in concert with each other to increase the pathogenicity of @gm$ A. sobria @/gm$. We purified a 65-kDa @gm$ A. sobria @/gm$ serine protease (ASP) from the culture supernatant and clarified its crystal structure. The overall structure of ASP is closely related to that of Kex2, a member of the kexin family of subtilases expressed by Saccharomyces cerevisiae. We further observed that ASP induces vascular leakage, reduces blood pressure by activating the kallikrein/kinin system, promotes human @di$ plasma coagulation @/di$ via the activation of prothrombin, and causes the formation of pus and edema through the action of anaphylatoxin C5a. ASP thus exerts a variety of effects on biological components and is deeply involved in the pathogenicity of @gm$ A. sobria @/gm$.

@gm$ Acidaminococcus fermentans @/gm$ belongs to the group of strictly anaerobic gram-negative cocci. All previously described @gm$ Acidaminococcus @/gm$ strains are susceptible to beta-lactam antibiotics. An A. fermentans strain (RYC-MR95) resistant to penicillin and expanded-spectrum cephalosporin (amoxicillin and cefotaxime MICs, 64 microgram/ml) was isolated from a human @di$ perianal abscess @/di$.

@gm$ Acinetobacter @/gm$ is a gram-negative coccobacillus, which naturally inhabits water and soil as well as pets, arthropods, and food animals. In humans, it can colonize skin, wounds, respiratory or gastrointestinal tracts as well as oral mucosa, predisposing to pneumonia in the event of aspiration into the lower respiratory tract. Certain @gm$ Acinetobacter @/gm$ species account for some healthcare-associated infections such as ventilator associated pneumonia, central line-associated @di$ bloodstream infections @/di$, catheter-associated urinary tract infections, and surgical site infections. @gm$ Acinetobacter junii @/gm$ is one species that is rarely reported to be a human infection. In this study, we presented a case of an isolated @gm$ Acinetobacter junii @/gm$ in urine culture, which was identified in a patient who had a left nephrostomy tube placement with prior antibiotic use.

@gm$ Acinetobacter @/gm$ species are opportunistic pathogens causing nosocomial infections . Relatively few infections caused by @gm$ Acinetobacter @/gm$ spp. are community-acquired, reported primarily from countries with tropical or subtropical climate, and mainly affected patients with some form of comorbidity or associated with heavy smoking and excess alcohol consumption . Clinical forms of Acinetobacter infections include mainly the respiratory tract, blood-stream infections, peritoneum, urinary tract infection, surgical wounds, @di$ meningitis @/di$, skin and soft tissue infections and eye infections.

@gm$ Acinetobacter @/gm$ spp. was cultured from eight donkeys (8/14, 57.1%) with vulvar discharge and four donkeys (4/16, 25%) with intrauterine fluid. P. aeruginosa was only cultured from seven donkeys (7/14, 50%) with vulvar discharge. SEZ was isolated from two (2/14, 14.3%) donkeys with purulent vulvar discharge and one donkey (1/16, 6.3%) with fluid in intrauterine. @di$ K. pneumonia @/di$ was cultured from two donkeys (2/16, 12.5%) with intrauterine fluid, while Klebsiella oxytoca was isolated from one donkey with discharge (1/14, 7.1%) and one donkey with fluid (1/16, 6.3%), respectively.

@gm$ Acinetobacter baumannii @/gm$ (@gm$ AB @/gm$), a gram-negative bacterium, is commonly present in the environment and can colonize the human intestinal tract and cause extensive infections, such as @di$ pneumonia @/di$, because of the patient's immunosuppressed condition. Lately, multidrug-resistant AB (MDRAB) has become an emerging problem in several hospitals and health settings because of its tendency to accumulate in hospital machinery, in which it can become resistance to antibiotics and difficulty in its eradication. Here, we report an unusual case of MDRAB-induced @di$ pneumonia @/di$ in a patient with RA receiving a TNFI.

@gm$ Acinetobacter johnsonii @/gm$ is usually found in the environment and animals, it can occasionally colonize human skin and cause clinical infections such as catheter-related bloodstream infections or @di$ peritonitis @/di$ associated with peritoneal dialysis.

@gm$ Aeromonas hydrophila @/gm$ caused severe disease in a group of Xenopus laevis within 3 weeks of receipt. The primary clinical signs were marked pallor of the skin, petechiation, lethargy, @di$ anorexia @/di$, and edema. The duration of the outbreak was approximately 45 days during which time 21 frogs became sick and 18 died, despite tetracycline therapy. Pale skin, subcutaneous edema and hemorrhages, ascites, and pale livers were seen at necropsy. @gm$ Aeromonas hydrophila @/gm$ was isolated from skin, and the same organism was isolated in pure culture from skeletal muscle. Tetracycline treatment via stomach tube was effective if given early in the course of the disease. The outbreak was controlled by removing sick frogs, feeding twice per week, changing the water several hours after feeding, and maintaining the frogs where the ambient temperature was 22 degrees C or lower. The pallor of the skin and general malaise were produced experimentally by crowding normal frogs, changing the water infrequently, and increasing ambient temperatures. Mild disease was reproduced experimentally by subcutaneous injection of @gm$ Aeromonas hydrophila @/gm$ into apparently healthy frogs.

@gm$ B. producta @/gm$ was described in 1941 and is commonly found in human feces. It has the capacity for rapid growth at the expense of carbon monoxide (CO) through anaerobic digestion. B. ovatus was first reported in 1933 and provides an inherent biosafety feature in the human gut. However, @gm$ B. producta @/gm$ is Gram-positive and B. ovatus is Gram-negative. According to previous studies, human ocular microbiota was characterized to be commonly identified in Gram-positive bacteria, while Acanthamoeba apparently prefer Gram-negative bacteria. Previous studies had demonstrated that amoebae prefer certain species of bacteria as a food source, such as P. aeruginosa and S. marcescens, but not S. epidermidis. It was presumed that the gram-positive cell wall was thick and hard to be digestion for Acanthamoeba. Therefore, the early-stage @di$ keratitis @/di$ isolates harbored abundant Gram-negative bacteria, with B. ovatus suspected as the early food source during initial infection. Notably, the relative abundance of B. ovatus was significantly higher in patients with atopic dermatitis as an immune disorder, whereas @gm$ B. producta @/gm$ had demonstrated prevention of Vancomycin-resistant Enterococcus (VRE) colonization.

@gm$ Bacillus cereus @/gm$ is a major causative agent of two distinct forms of gastroenteritis diseases linked to food poisoning:emesis and diarrhea:as well as extra-intestinal infections, including @di$ endocarditis @/di$, endophthalmitis, and septicemia.

@gm$ Bacillus cereus @/gm$ is capable of producing emesis toxin (ETE) and three enterotoxins, including hemolytic enterotoxin (HBL), nonhemolytic enterotoxin (NHE), and enterotoxin K (EntK), of which HBL and NHE are important enterotoxins that cause @di$ diarrhea @/di$-based food poisoning. There are five virulence genes associated with the production of these enterotoxins: hemolysin BL gene (hbl), non-hemolytic enterotoxin gene (nhe), enterotoxin FM gene (entFM), enterotoxin T gene (becT), and cytotoxin K gene (cytK). HBL requires all three genes positive for hblA, hblC, and hblD to be toxic, while NHE is most toxic when all three genes are positive for nheA, nheB, and nheC. The virulence gene expressing vomitoxin is ces gene, which encodes a heat-resistant toxin that is not easily cleaved. A total of 24 virulence gene carriage patterns of @gm$ B. cereus @/gm$ were identified, among which the nhe gene had the highest carriage rate of 92.98%, followed by the entFM gene (71.93%), and 70.18% of strains carried both nhe and entFM genes.

@gm$ Bacteroides fragilis @/gm$ was added to the sterile pellet to study the effect of an anaerobic monoclonal abscess (16 rats) or of a biclonal abscess containing both aerobes and anaerobes (32 rats). After inoculation, a peritonitis stage with leucopenia, hypoglycemia, body @di$ weight loss @/di$, and slight fever was followed by the abscess stage with leucocytosis and a slight hyperglycemia. Mild hepatic energy charge deficiency and hepatic lactic acidosis were observed in sterile abscess rats, and slightly enhanced energy charge was seen in monoclonal E. coli abscess rats. The addition of @gm$ B. fragilis @/gm$ to the sterile pellet, alone or together with E.

@gm$ Bacteroides xylanisolvens @/gm$ showed a greater abundance in PCOS-IR when compared to control-IR. It was found to be specialized in the degradation of xylans with low complexity. Christensenellaceae spp. were shown to have increased relative abundance in the control group. The relative abundance of the Christensenellaceae family has a negative relationship with BMI, LDL, and apolipoprotein B as well as features of metabolic syndrome such as @di$ obesity @/di$ and hypertriglyceridemia, and was positively associated with HDL.

@gm$ Barnesiella @/gm$ is a genus in the family of Porphyromonadaceae, and is associated with hyperglycemia, @di$ insulin resistance @/di$, hepatic steatosis, and inflammation in rodents (Le). @gm$ Barnesiella @/gm$ is also one of the most abundant genera in human feces and can be used to treat vancomycin-resistant Streptococcus faecalis colonization. In addition, it has been reported that @gm$ Barnesiella intestinihominis @/gm$ from @gm$ Barnesiella @/gm$ is an intestinal symbiotic bacteria, which can change the tumor microenvironment, reduce regulatory T cells, stimulate the anti-cancer immunomodulator cyclophosphamide (CTL) reaction, and further promote the antitumor efficacy of cyclophosphamide (CTX). In the present study, the relative abundances of @gm$ Barnesiella @/gm$ in HC and LC groups were significantly lower than in the MC group, indicating @gm$ Barnesiella @/gm$ as one of the most abundant genera in broilers, with its abundance influenced by both heat and cold stresses.

@gm$ Bifidobacterium @/gm$ is frequently isolated from the human intestine, but @gm$ Bifidobacterium dentium @/gm$ is known to be present in the human oral cavity, as well as in the intestine. @gm$ B. dentium @/gm$ is frequently isolated from active carious lesions and thus may contribute to the pathogenesis of dental caries. Possession of an enzyme activity that degrades artificial trypsin substrates, such as benzoylarginine-beta-naphthylamide, has been proposed as a possible virulence factor in the suspected @di$ periodontal pathogens @/di$. @gm$ B. dentium @/gm$, which is one of the periodontal bacterial isolates, also has this activity. @gm$ B. dentium @/gm$ belongs to the Bifidobacterium adolescentis group.

@gm$ Bifidobacterium @/gm$ spp. can be detected in various ecological environments, such as intestines of different vertebrates and invertebrates, dairy products, @di$ dental caries @/di$ and sewage. Considering the increasing application of @gm$ Bifidobacterium @/gm$ spp. as protective and probiotic cultures , and the fast enlargement of the genus, easy identification tools to discriminate new isolates are essential. Moreover, their correct taxonomic identification is of outmost importance for their use as probiotics . Conventional identification and classification of @gm$ Bifidobacterium @/gm$ species have been based on phenotypic and biochemical features, such as cell morphology, carbohydrate fermentation profiles, and polyacrylamide gel electrophoresis analysis of soluble cellular proteins . In the last years several molecular techniques have been proposed in order to identify bifidobacteria. Most available bifidobacterial identification tools are based on 16S rRNA gene sequence analysis, such as ARDRA , DGGE  and PCR with the use of species-specific primers . However, 16S rDNA of @gm$ Bifidobacterium @/gm$ spp.

@gm$ Bilophila wadsworthia @/gm$, a recently described anaerobic gram-negative bacillus, was isolated from blood cultures of two patients with @di$ liver abscesses @/di$. These isolates exhibited the expected phenotypic characteristics, and identification was confirmed by cell wall fatty acid analysis by gas-liquid chromatography. This is the first documentation of bacteremia due to @gm$ B. wadsworthia @/gm$.

@gm$ Brachyspira @/gm$ (@gm$ B.) pilosicoli @/gm$ and B. aalborgi are candidate causal agents of large intestinal spirochetosis. These spirochetes are also related to @di$ adenocarcinoma @/di$, polyps, diarrhea containing blood and ulcerative colitis (UC). However, the pathogenesis mechanisms of these agents are not yet fully understood. We are interested in the relationship between the pathogenesis of ulcerative colitis and intestinal brachyspiral infection. Recently, the presence of brachyspiras was confirmed by histological investigation of patients with intestinal spirochetosis syndrome i.e. @di$ adenocarcinoma @/di$, UC, polyps, diarrhea with blood and septicemia. In addition, the presence of two different genes of the brachyspiral species has been reported on a patient with large intestinal spirochetosis. We therefore attempted and succeeded in simultaneous isolation of both species, @gm$ B. pilosicoli @/gm$ and B.

@gm$ Brachyspira pilosicoli @/gm$ is an anaerobic spirochaete that colonizes the large intestine of humans and various species of animals and birds. The spirochaete is an important enteric pathogen of pigs and poultry, but its pathogenic potential in humans is less clear. In the current study, the occurrence of @gm$ B. pilosicoli @/gm$ in faecal samples from 766 individuals in two different population groups in Perth, Western Australia, was investigated by selective anaerobic culture. Of 586 individuals who were long-term residents of Perth, including children, elderly patients in care and in hospital and individuals with @di$ gastrointestinal disease @/di$, only one was culture positive. This person had a history of diverticulitis. In comparison, faeces from 17 of 180 (9.4 %) Indonesians who were short- or medium-term visitors to Perth were positive for @gm$ B. pilosicoli @/gm$. The culture-positive individuals had been in the city for between 10 days and 4.5 years (median 5 months). Resampling of subsets of the Indonesians indicated that all negative people remained negative and that some positive individuals remained positive after 5 months. Two individuals had pairs of isolates recovered after 4 and 5 months that had the same PFGE types, whilst another individual had isolates with two different PFGE types that were identified 2 months apart. Individuals who were culture-positive were likely to have been either colonized in Indonesia before arriving in Perth or infected in Perth following contact with other culture-positive Indonesians with whom they socialized. Colonization with @gm$ B. pilosicoli @/gm$ was not significantly associated with clinical signs at the time the individuals were tested, although faeces with wet-clay consistency were 1.5 times more likely (confidence interval 0.55-4.6) than normal faeces to contain @gm$ B. pilosicoli @/gm$.

@gm$ Brucella @/gm$ infection is characterized by non-specific symptoms including general body malaise, @di$ anorexia @/di$, fever, back pain, headache, lethargy and many other clinical presentations that often mimic other diseases causing pyrexia such as malaria and typhoid fever. Its ability to survive and multiply within immune cells such as macrophages results into chronic debilitating disease with poor prognosis in most of the cases. In addition, the treatment requires multiple antibiotics for prolonged duration. Despite being important, zoonotic disease data regarding the epidemiology of @gm$ Brucella @/gm$ infection among high-risk groups are scarce in developing countries including Tanzania.

@gm$ Brucella @/gm$ is an intracellular parasitic bacterium causing zoonosis, which is distributed worldwide and mainly characterized by @di$ reproductive disorders @/di$. Erythritol is found in allantoic fluid, chorion, and placenta of aborted animals, preferentially utilized by @gm$ Brucella @/gm$ to cause infertility and abortion. However, the erythritol metabolism-defected mutant was unable to function as a vaccine strain due to its residual virulence. Here, we found that erythronate, an oxidative product of erythritol in the host, was also preferentially utilized by @gm$ Brucella @/gm$ relying on the function of a deoxyribonucleoside regulator-family transcriptional regulator VdtR. Erythronate utilization activates VdtR regulation of the erythronate metabolic pathway to promote @gm$ Brucella @/gm$ extracellular proliferation, inducing placentitis/abortion in mice. Double mutations on Brucella erythritol and D-erythronate metabolisms significantly reduced bacterial virulence. This study revealed a novel mechanism of Brucella infection-induced abortion, thus providing a new clue for the study of safer @gm$ Brucella @/gm$ attenuated vaccines.

@gm$ Brucella @/gm$ species can cause systemic disease in humans, especially damages to the reproductive system and joints of the individuals. However, the incidence of neurological involvement is rare, with about 2 to 5% of patients involved with the nervous system. Neurobrucellosis (NB) is the most serious complication of brucellosis, which can involve the CNS and the peripheral nervous system. The main clinical presentations of the patients include meningitis, @di$ encephalitis @/di$, meningoencephalitis, radiculitis, myelitis, optic neuritis, and behavioral abnormalities, among which meningitis is the most common presentation accounting for 17 to 74% of NB.

@gm$ Brucella abortus @/gm$ is the causative agent of brucellosis, which causes abortion in domestic animals and undulant @di$ fever @/di$ in humans. This bacterium infects and proliferates mainly in macrophages and dendritic cells, where it is recognized by pattern recognition receptors (PRRs) including Nod-like receptors (NLRs). Our group recently demonstrated the role of AIM2 and NLRP3 in Brucella recognition. Here, we investigated the participation of NLRP12 in innate immune response to @gm$ B. abortus @/gm$. We show that NLRP12 inhibits the early production of IL-12 by bone marrow-derived macrophages upon B. abortus infection. We also observed that NLRP12 suppresses in vitro NF-kappaB and MAPK signaling in response to Brucella. Moreover, we show that NLRP12 modulates caspase-1 activation and IL-1beta secretion in @gm$ B. abortus @/gm$ infected-macrophages. Furthermore, we show that mice lacking NLRP12 are more resistant in the early stages of B. abortus infection: NLRP12-/- infected-mice have reduced bacterial burdens in the spleens and increased production of IFN-gamma and IL-1beta compared with wild-type controls. In addition, NLRP12 deficiency leads to reduction in granuloma number and size in mouse livers. Altogether, our findings suggest that NLRP12 plays an important role in negatively regulating the early inflammatory responses against @gm$ B. abortus @/gm$.

@gm$ Brucella abortus @/gm$, the etiology of bovine brucellosis, is a highly infectious pathogenic bacterial organism that causes infertility, abortion and reproductive failure in cattle (Carvalho-Neta et al., 2010). Brucellosis spreads through contact with aborted foetuses, vaginal fluids, placentae, placental fluids and milk, as well as through congenital and venereal means (Franco et al., 2007). It is one of the major @di$ zoonotic diseases @/di$ of livestock with worldwide occurrence (Pappas et al., 2006) that usually results in huge economic losses due to reproductive problems that include abortion, early calf death, infertility, low milk yield, orchitis, epididymitis, seminal vesiculitis and other problems.

@gm$ Brucella canis @/gm$ is a gram-negative coccobacillary bacterium that primarily causes reproductive failure in dogs. The genus @gm$ Brucella @/gm$ comprises 12 recognized species. Of these, B. melitensis, B. abortus, and B. suis are well-known causes of undulant fever and @di$ influenza-like symptoms @/di$ in humans, but B.

@gm$ Brucella canis @/gm$ was isolated from the cement or bone surrounding a hip prosthesis after total hip replacement was performed for treatment of hip dysplasia in 2 dogs. Lameness or signs of infection were not evident for 9 and 16 months after surgery. @di$ Osteomyelitis @/di$ surrounding the prostheses was detected radiographically only after the lameness developed.

@gm$ Brucella ovis @/gm$ is a rough, Gram-negative, non-spore-forming, non-motile and facultative intracellular bacterium. In rams, the microorganism causes mainly epididymitis, whereas in ewes the lesions are characterized by degeneration and @di$ inflammation @/di$ of the endometrium with focal or diffuse lymphoid infiltrations.

@gm$ Brucella ovis @/gm$ is a stably rough Gram-negative coccobacillus, not encapsulated, not sporulated, that belongs to the alpha-2-Proteobacteria family. Ovine brucellosis caused by @gm$ B. ovis @/gm$ has worldwide distribution in all areas where sheep-raising has economic importance. Infection with @gm$ B. ovis @/gm$ is characterized by unilateral @di$ epididymitis @/di$ in males (or bilateral, although less common), testicular degeneration and/or atrophy, that may result in subfertility, causing large economic losses. In ewes, B. ovis infection can lead to abortion or birth of weak offspring, leading to perinatal death. Importantly, @gm$ B. ovis @/gm$ is not been associated with human infections.

@gm$ Brucella suis @/gm$ (@gm$ B. suis @/gm$) is the causative agent of porcine brucellosis. Based on preferential infection of different animal hosts, it encompasses five biovars (bv1-5). Biovars 1, 2, and 3 infect domestic pigs, wild boars, and hares, bv 4 is restricted to reindeer and caribou, and bv 5 infects rodents only. Biovar 1 is widely spread in Central and South American pigs, causing several brucellosis outbreaks in pigs, and is linked to zoonotic human infections. Biovars 1 and 3 cause sporadic epidemics in Asia, especially in China. Biovar 4 is endemic to Alaska, Canada, and Northern Russia. It was reported as a rare cause of human disease. On the contrary, biovar 2 is restricted to Europe, where both wild boar (Sus scrofa scrofa) and European brown hare (Lepus europaeus) are the only recognized wildlife reservoirs of this biovar. Recently, an emerging increase of biovar 2 brucellosis outbreaks in pigs was reported in Europe. These outbreaks mainly were linked to contact of domestic pigs with wildlife reservoirs, import of carrier pigs, or use of infected boar semen. Additionally, spillover infections spread to cattle were reported in several European countries. @gm$ B. suis bv @/gm$ 2 causes bacteremia, abortion, stillbirths, decreased litter size, weak piglets, infertility, and sometimes chronic focal localization as abscess formation in various organs, metritis in females, @di$ orchitis @/di$ in males, and swollen joints with lameness. @gm$ B. suis bv @/gm$ 2 outbreaks have been associated with a high economic impact on the pig industry in Europe.

@gm$ C. butyricum @/gm$ administration has been shown to alleviate allergic responses, again possibly by the modulation of Tregs (Figure 3). In a mouse model of asthma, @gm$ C. butyricum @/gm$ CGMCC0313.1 reduced airway hyperresponsiveness and @di$ lung inflammation @/di$ by suppressing the Th2 response and increasing anti-inflammatory IL-10. In asthmatic lungs, mast cells infiltrate the airway and degranulate, releasing inflammatory molecules and proteases that result in tissue swelling. In lungs from mice administered @gm$ C. butyricum @/gm$, the number of infiltrating immune cells, level of Th2 cytokines (IL-4 and IL-5), markers of mast cell degranulation, and levels of IgE were all decreased. Similarly, in a food allergy mouse model, @gm$ C. butyricum @/gm$ CGMCC0313.1 treatment resulted in attenuation of allergic reaction, along with an increased measure of forkhead box P3 (Foxp3), an indication of increased Treg. Pre - or post-treatment with @gm$ C. butyricum @/gm$ reduced the severity of diarrhea and anaphylaxis, as well as circulating mast cell proteases, IgE, and Th2 cytokines IL-4, IL-5, and IL-13. Increased abundance of Tregs in the intestine (mesenteric lymph node) and the associated cytokines IL-10 and TGF-beta in the serum were noted. Thus, @gm$ C. butyricum @/gm$ attenuates the Th2 response-driven allergic reaction and the associated inflammation by mediating the Th2/Treg balance.

@gm$ C. concisus @/gm$ @gm$ ATCC 33237 @/gm$ is the type strain of this species and was sequenced to completion. One strain, CCUG 19995, was isolated in 1987 in Sweden from a patient with pyrexia and exanthema. The remaining seven strains (Lasto28.99, Lasto61.99, Lasto64.99, Lasto127.99, Lasto205.94, Lasto220.96, and Lasto393.96) were isolated in South Africa between 1994 and 1999 from patients with dysentery, @di$ diarrhea @/di$, or loose mucoid stools.

@gm$ C. concisus @/gm$ isolates obtained from the majority of the patients with IBD (6/8) formed one cluster (Cluster 1). The @gm$ C. concisus @/gm$ strain (P1CDB1(UNSWCD)) isolated from intestinal biopsies of patient No. 1 with CD, C. concisus strain 13826 (a strain isolated from fecal sample of a patient with @di$ bloody diarrhea @/di$) and the oral @gm$ C. concisus @/gm$ isolate obtained from healthy individual No. 3 were also grouped into Cluster 1. All enteric invasive @gm$ Campylobacter concisus @/gm$ (EICC) strains (see results in Table 2) were grouped into Cluster 1 (Figure 1). Seven of the eight individuals (7/8, 87.5%) whose isolates belonged to Cluster 1 had inflammatory enteric diseases (six patients with IBD and one had @di$ bloody diarrhea @/di$), which was significantly higher than the remaining individuals (2/7, 28.6%) (P<0.05). Among the @gm$ C. concisus @/gm$ isolates that did not belong to Cluster 1, six isolates were genetically closely related, forming a second cluster (Cluster 2). The oral @gm$ C. concisus @/gm$ isolate obtained from a healthy control (H6O1) was genetically distinct from the other @gm$ C. concisus @/gm$ isolates (Figure 1).

@gm$ C. eutactus @/gm$ is an obligate anaerobe that and is a constituent of healthy guts but is present at the lowest abundance in the irritable bowel syndrome D subtype. @gm$ C. eutactus @/gm$ leads to the production of butyrate, while Coprococcus species are generally associated with a better quality of life and are depleted in depression. Another obligate anaerobe, D. longicatena, is negatively correlated with markers of dyslipidaemia or @di$ insulin resistance @/di$, indicating its beneficial probiotic effect.
@gm$ C. fetus @/gm$ typically enters the blood stream from the gastrointestinal tract in susceptible hosts. Bacteremia is often preceded or accompanied by @di$ diarrhea @/di$, as seen in our case.

@gm$ CB @/gm$ can also be used as an adjunct to current therapies. The research of Tian et al. has shown that @gm$ CB @/gm$ reduces adverse events, especially @di$ diarrhea @/di$, caused by chemotherapy for lung cancer. Furthermore, @gm$ CB @/gm$ exhibits a synergistic effect when combined with lapatinib treatment for colon tumors in mice. In ICB therapy, @gm$ CB @/gm$ therapy can enhance the efficacy even in antibiotic-treated patients and is associated with longer progression-free survival and overall survival.
@gm$ Campylobacter @/gm$ can also cause @di$ invasive diseases @/di$, including bacteraemia. We found two cases of bacteraemia due to @gm$ Campylobacter @/gm$.

@gm$ Campylobacter @/gm$ colonizes the human oral cavity, and some strains can be transferred to the intestine, which play an important role in the development of inflammatory bowel disease (IBD), @di$ Barrett's oesophagus @/di$, and gastroenteritis.

@gm$ Campylobacter coli @/gm$ are one of the most common bacteria in bacterial gastroenteritis and @di$ acute enterocolitis @/di$ in humans. However, relatively little is known regarding the mechanisms of pathogenesis and host response to C. coli infections. To investigate the influence of genetic changes, we first used PCR to demonstrate the presence of the known virulence genes cadF, virB11, cdtB, cdtC and ceuE in the clinical isolate C. coli 26536, which was isolated from the liver of infected BALB/c mice. Sequence analyses of the cadF, virB11, cdtB and ceuE genes in C. coli 26536 confirmed the stability in these virulence genes during their transmission through the host. We further investigated C. coli infection for the bacterial clearance from the liver and spleen of infected mice, and for their immune response. @gm$ C. coli @/gm$ persisted well in both organs, with better survival in the liver.

@gm$ Campylobacter concisus @/gm$ BAA-1457 was also found to upregulate a range of pathways and processes associated with EMT, as well as IGF family signaling in colorectal cancer. Further, the strain isolated from a healthy individual (ATCC 51561) did not appear to upregulate EMT. Notably, studies have found that Campylobacter species are among a polymicrobial signature of Gram-negative bacteria (including Fusobacterium) that are enriched in colorectal cancer patient samples, suggesting that the presence of some types of @gm$ C. concisus @/gm$ strains in the gut may have the potential to promote functions associated with carcinogenesis. Moreover, a similar polymicrobial signature comprising Campylobacter and Fusobacterium species is enriched in patients in the early stages of the oesophageal adenocarcinoma cascade (@di$ gastro-oesophageal reflux disease @/di$ and Barrett's oesophagus). Thus, it would be interesting to determine if some @gm$ C. concisus @/gm$ strains can regulate EMT in oesophageal epithelial cells.

@gm$ Campylobacter jejuni @/gm$ and C. coli are common inhabitants of the gastrointestinal tracts of animals and are regarded as the most frequent causes of acute bacterial enteritis in humans. The main pathways by which humans acquire infection are the consumption of undercooked poultry meat, food cross-contaminated with raw poultry product, water contaminated with @gm$ Campylobacter @/gm$ from animals or humans, and direct contact with animals or human clinical campylobacteriosis cases. Campylobacteriosis in humans is usually a self-limiting condition involving @di$ diarrhea @/di$, abdominal cramping, and fever of up to 2 weeks' duration. However, neonates, the elderly, and individuals with immune disorders might develop more serious symptoms that necessitate antimicrobial therapy. In such cases, macrolides such as erythromycin are the first choice for treatment, although in many countries the use of ciprofloxacin (a fluoroquinolone) is used preferred on an empirical basis. The emergence of resistance to fluoroquinolones in @gm$ Campylobacter @/gm$ spp., combined with the high incidence of Campylobacter infections in humans, is a major concern for public health.

@gm$ Clostridium @/gm$ species are spore-forming gram-positive anaerobic bacilli ubiquitous soil organisms often found in the digestive tract of humans . C. perfringens produces an alpha toxin, which is associated with cytoskeletal disruption and resulting vascular leak. The early signs of @gm$ Clostridium @/gm$ toxic shock syndrome are nonspecific; they include lethargy, pallor, nausea, vomiting, and pain at the site of infection. The syndrome is notable for the absence of fever. After 48-72 hours of infection, the patients develop refractory hypotension, severe @di$ tachycardia @/di$, extensive peripheral edema, effusions, hemoconcentration, and leukemoid reaction.

@gm$ Clostridium butyricum @/gm$ (@gm$ CB @/gm$), an endospore-producing probiotic, is a promising product with the stronger resistance to stress (e.g. acid, alkali, high temperature and antibiotics) and the better adaptability to the gastrointestinal environment than other probiotics. The previous reports have indicated that @gm$ CB @/gm$ functions for the regulating energy metabolism, the promoting digestion and absorption, anti-inflammatory, anti-oxidative and also anti-cancer in humans and animals. This microbe can also regulate the intestinal microecological balance in host by inhibiting the growth of drug-resistant strains and increasing the colonization of butyrate-producing beneficial bacteria. Butyrate, a main product of @gm$ CB @/gm$ bacteria, plays a key role in repairing intestinal mucosal damage and maintaining the intestinal microecological balance. For example, the @gm$ CB @/gm$ MIYAIRI 588 strain can increase the number of beneficial bacteria, such as Bifidobacterium, protect the mucin layer of the intestinal epithelium by producing lactic acid and butyric acid, and therefore effectively reversing clindamycin-induced @di$ intestinal dysbiosis @/di$. In Japan, the @gm$ CB @/gm$ has been widely used in the prevention and treatment of gastrointestinal infections. Recently, we have obtained a new @gm$ CB strain @/gm$ that derived from the healthy adult pigs. The bacterium is named @gm$ Clostridium butyricum @/gm$ XKYQRL 2021 (CBX 2021) and it produces spores and has good growth characteristics and stable metabolic function.

@gm$ Clostridium butyricum @/gm$:a Gram-positive, anaerobic, spore-forming bacillus:can consume undigested dietary fibers and produce short-chain fatty acids (SCFAs), specifically butyrate and acetate. The administration of @gm$ C. butyricum @/gm$, both in clinical practice and animal models, have had a beneficial effect on inflammatory bowel disease, intestinal tumor development, as well as cerebral ischemia, and obesity, without serious side effects in Asia  . The protection of @gm$ C. butyricum @/gm$ on liver diseases has also been demonstrated well in animal models, such as the role of modulating TLR signaling pathways in high-fat, diet-induced @di$ liver injury @/di$  , and in relieving the CCl4-induced oxidative stress and inflammation in the @di$ liver @/di$ by regulating NF-kappaB, IL-10 and the gut microbiota in mice. It was firmly established that intravenous administration of butyrate protects LPS-induced @di$ liver injury @/di$ by inhibiting the inflammation  . Partially building on this knowledge and inspired by research on the role of @gm$ C. butyricum @/gm$ dietary supplementation in the disease pathophysiology of the @di$ liver @/di$ and other organs, this study investigated the possibility that @gm$ C. butyricum @/gm$ dietary supplementation attenuates HIRI in rats.

@gm$ Clostridium sordellii @/gm$ is a common soil and enteric bacterium that is infrequently recovered from the vagina. We describe three women in which @gm$ C. sordellii @/gm$ caused puerperal infection and a distinctive and lethal toxic shock-like syndrome. Patients were less than 1 week post partum and each had a single, limited focus of infection including infection associated with a retained vaginal sponge, a cesarean section operative site, and endometritis. Each patient had a distinctive course characterized by sudden onset of clinical @di$ shock @/di$ marked by severe and unrelenting hypotension associated with marked, generalized tissue edema and "third spacing" with increased hematocrit, presence of marked leukemoid reaction with total neutrophil counts of 84,000/mm3, 66,000/mm3, and 93,600/mm3, absence of rash or fever, limited or no myonecrosis, and a rapid and uniformly lethal course. Hypoalbuminemia was also noted. Similar findings were noted in prior isolated reports of @gm$ C. sordellii @/gm$-mediated postpartum or surgical infection. Treatment of animals with @gm$ C. sordellii @/gm$ or closely related C. difficile toxins produces similar findings. We suggest that localized infection with toxin-producing strains of @gm$ C. sordellii @/gm$ can produce a rapidly lethal toxic shock-like syndrome.

@gm$ Cronobacter sakazakii @/gm$ is a rod-shaped, non-spore-forming, peritrichous, facultative anaerobic Gram-negative foodborne pathogen, belonging to the Enterobacteriaceae family (Stephan et al.,). @gm$ C. sakazakii @/gm$ is occasionally detected in meat, vegetables, cereals and dairy (Beuchat et al.,). In particular, powdered infant formula has been linked with many C. sakazakii infections, according to an epidemiological report (Yan et al.,). @gm$ C. sakazakii @/gm$ contamination more frequently causes infection in infants or adults with lowered immunity, suffering from @di$ bacteremia @/di$, meningitis, necrotizing enterocolitis or other diseases, and a lethality rate of more than 50% has been reported (Ye et al.,).

@gm$ Cronobacter sakazakii @/gm$ is an emerging foodborne pathogen, causing life-threatening forms of neonatal meningitis, sepsis, and NEC in newborn and premature infants, with a fatality rate of 40% to 80%. In addition to its high-fatality rate, it may also result in severe neurological sequelae such as quadriplegia, @di$ hydrocephalus @/di$ and retarded neural development in survivors. The environmental source of @gm$ C. sakazakii @/gm$ is not evidently understood; however, the epidemiological studies implicate reconstituted powdered infant formula (PIF) as the possible source of transmission. Survival of bacteria in such a dry environment largely depends on the osmotic and/or dry stress resistance of the bacteria. Our laboratory has previously reported the prevalence of @gm$ C. sakazakii @/gm$ among different food and environmental commodities. The isolates expressed different virulent factors such as hemolytic and chitinase activity along with the presence of genes encoding for hemolysin, outer membrane protein (ompA), @gm$ Cronobacter @/gm$ plasminogen activator (cpa) and ferric ion transporter protein (eitA).

@gm$ Cronobacter sakazakii @/gm$ is an opportunistic pathogen known to cause acute @di$ meningitis @/di$ and necrotizing enterocolitis in neonates and immunocompromised individuals. It has been isolated from a wide range of food and environmental samples, and has been linked to outbreaks associated with powdered infant formula. This study was carried out to assess variations in growth conditions (temperature, pH, and sugar supplement) and to establish how these changes impact phenotypic characteristics for successful recovery and identification of @gm$ Cronobacter @/gm$, particularly for routine surveillance purposes. A total of six @gm$ Cronobacter @/gm$ isolates were tested to evaluate the above growth conditions, including three ATCC @gm$ Cronobacter @/gm$ reference and three environmental isolates obtained from regulatory sample screening. Although only slight changes in colony-forming units were observed across the pH range and the sugars tested, the morphology was significantly impacted by changes in these growth factors. Incubation between 30 and 50  C resulted in growth after 24 h, and the growth was slower at ambient temperature and colony formation was most robust at 30  C. Results of this study suggest that 30  C may be suitable for recovery of some @gm$ Cronobacter @/gm$ strains, and minor variations in growth conditions can alter colony morphology and appearance. Expression of unique biological characteristics based on phenotypic observations may be beneficial for differentiating various @gm$ Cronobacter @/gm$ strains.

@gm$ E. coli @/gm$ displays a peculiar genome plasticity that enables the flow of genes in and out of the cell, generating high variability of the gene content among lineages that include resistance and virulence genes. Within this species, extraintestinal pathogenic @gm$ E. coli @/gm$ (ExPEC) is a versatile pathotype that typically causes urinary tract infections, pyelonephritis, sepsis, pneumonia, and @di$ meningitis @/di$.

@gm$ E. hirae @/gm$ is an organism seldom reported to cause human infections. Here, we report a case of a biliary tract infection in a female patient with cholangiocarcinoma caused by @gm$ E. hirae @/gm$. CASE: A 56-year-old female presented with fever and abdominal pain. Bile aspirated during the ERCP was received in our laboratory. The gram stain of the bile sample revealed abundant polymorphonuclear leucocytes along with gram-positive diplococci. The organism failed to grow on MacConkey agar. On blood agar, non-hemolytic colonies grew. The organism was identified as @gm$ E. hirae @/gm$ by MALDI-TOF MS. The antibiotic susceptibility performed using VITEK2 revealed it to be resistant to high-level gentamicin and susceptible to all remaining drugs. She was successfully treated with oral ciprofloxacin for the infection. DISCUSSION: Bile is colonized with bacteria due to obstruction in the biliary tree, leading to @di$ cholangitis @/di$. This causes bacterial proliferation and translocation of bacteria into the systemic circulation. Our case was resistant to high-level gentamicin, while all previously reported cases were susceptible. The resistant isolates of @gm$ E. hirae @/gm$ being isolated from cattle and their surroundings amidst the rampant use of antibiotics in livestock can pose a difficult situation for humans. Thus, there should be regulations on antibiotic usage in livestock. Cases like these should be reported and recognized for their potential to cause outbreaks if they remain unreported. CONCLUSION: Thus, @gm$ E.hirae @/gm$, when encountered, should not be ignored but considered a pathogen and reported.

@gm$ Eggerthella lenta @/gm$ is an anaerobic, non-spore-forming gram-positive bacillus that is among the natural members of the gut microbiota. Previous studies have shown that Th17 activation may have effects on related inflammatory diseases, familial Mediterranean fever, some infections, and @di$ autoimmune diseases @/di$. Crohn's disease, ulcerative colitis, multiple sclerosis, and rheumatoid arthritis were found to be higher in the Behcet's disease group than in the Eggerthella control group at the genus level. In our study, a significant increase was observed in the MIS-C group at both the genus (@gm$ Eggerthella @/gm$) and species levels (@gm$ Eggerthella lenta @/gm$). Considering autoimmunity and the Th17 pathway in the pathogenesis of MIS-C, our findings suggest that an increase in @gm$ Eggerthella lenta @/gm$ may be associated with the pathogenesis.

@gm$ Eggerthella lenta @/gm$ was first described by Arnold Eggerth in 1935, which was originally named @gm$ Eubacterium lentum @/gm$. @gm$ E. lenta @/gm$ is a normal bacterium that can colonize the human gut, female reproductive tract, oral cavity, and prostate gland. Due to the nature of strictly anaerobic and slow growth, @gm$ E. lenta @/gm$ is difficult to culture and identify. Although, until recently, several microbial identification techniques, particularly mass spectrometry, were used to identify bacteria, an increasing number of @gm$ E. lenta @/gm$ infections in humans have been reported, referring to bloodstream infection, liver abscess, bacterial vaginosis and @di$ meningitis @/di$. However, a unified standard treatment and its pathogenic mechanism have not yet been recognized. Here, we report cases of @gm$ E. lenta @/gm$ bacteremia cured by ceftizoxime and review the existing recent literature. This article aims to add to existing data for the timely diagnosis and treatment of @gm$ E. lenta @/gm$ bacteremia.

@gm$ Enterobacter @/gm$ is a genus of facultative Gram-negative anaerobes that belongs to the Enterobacteriaceae family. These opportunistic pathogens commonly target immunocompromised hosts, who are implanted with IMD or on mechanical ventilation. The genus has been implicated in a wide spectrum of nosocomial infections, namely urinary and respiratory tract infections. Subsequently, patients with a prolonged hospital stay, especially those in ICU are at increased risk of contracting associated infections. Given the ubiquitous nature of @gm$ Enterobacter @/gm$, infections can be acquired from both endogenous and exogenous source. However, most nosocomial infections are contracted endogenously from previously colonised patients who have received prior antibiotic therapy. Among the different species of @gm$ Enterobacter @/gm$, @gm$ E. aerogenes @/gm$ and E. cloacae are the two most frequently encountered pathogens in patients; although the former species has been speculated to belong to the Klebsiella genus. E. cloacae, especially, currently accounts for 4%-5% of all nosocomial bacteraemia, pneumoniae and @di$ urinary tract infections @/di$. Due to the species diversity of the genus itself, antimicrobial susceptibility varies widely within @gm$ Enterobacter @/gm$, however, both E. cloacae and @gm$ E. aerogenes @/gm$ are almost uniformly resistant to ampicillin, cephalothin, cefoxitin and other beta-lactam drugs, among others. Both species have demonstrated the intrinsic ability to form biofilm, however, due to their relative prevalence among the @gm$ Enterobacter @/gm$ genus, biofilm production has predominantly been studied in E.

@gm$ Enterobacter cloacae @/gm$ is a gram negative bacillus that is ubiquitous as a contaminant and a pathogen in adult, paediatric, and neonatal ICUs. Its transmission is almost exclusively nosocomial with community acquired infection reported rarely. We report a case of community acquired, rapidly progressive @gm$ E. cloacae @/gm$ @di$ meningo-encephalitis @/di$ in a neonate. A three-week-old term infant presented from home, having been discharged from hospital within two days of delivery. She rapidly progressed to multi-organ dysfunction. Initial CT of her brain showed evidence of severe hypoxic changes and herniation of the frontal lobes through the anterior fontanelle. Care was withdrawn 72 hours after admission. Post mortem examination confirmed @gm$ E.cloacae @/gm$ @di$ meningo-encephalitis @/di$ as a cause of her death. The baby had not been in a critical care environment at any time before admission, making it highly likely to have been a community acquired infection. Transmission of the organism may have been vertical as maternal transmission with intestinal colonization of neonates with @gm$ E. cloacae @/gm$ has previously been reported. This case confirms that infection with @gm$ E. cloacae @/gm$ should be included in the differential diagnosis of any severely ill neonate presenting from the community, and antimicrobial therapy should be optimized accordingly.

@gm$ Erysipelothrix rhusiopathiae @/gm$ causes @di$ erysipelas @/di$ in swine and is considered a reemerging disease contributing substantially to economic losses in the swine industry. Since an attenuated live vaccine was commercialized in 1974 in Japan, outbreaks of acute septicemia or subacute urticaria of @di$ erysipelas @/di$ have decreased dramatically. In contrast, a chronic form of @di$ erysipelas @/di$ found during meat inspections in slaughterhouses has been increasing.

@gm$ Erysipelothrix rhusiopathiae @/gm$ septicemia, associated with an increased mortality of captive psittacines in a mixed-species aviary, was diagnosed by histopathology, Gram staining, bacterial culture and sequencing, immunohistochemistry, and real-time polymerase chain reaction (PCR). Over a period of 23 days with no premonitory signs, 2 rainbow lorikeets and an eclectus parrot died. Of these birds, one lorikeet and the eclectus were submitted for necropsy. The main pathologic findings were thrombosis (2/2), bacterial embolism/thromboembolism (2/2), necrotizing hepatitis (2/2), necrohemorrhagic myocarditis (1/2), fibrinohemorrhagic and heterophilic visceral coelomitis (1/2), submandibular necrosuppurative dermatitis with necrotizing @di$ vasculitis @/di$ and bacterial and fungal thromboembolism (1/2), and locally extensive rhabdomyonecrosis with bacterial embolism (1/2). Intralesional bacteria were positive by Gram staining and immunohistochemistry in both cases. @gm$ E. rhusiopathiae @/gm$ was isolated by routine bacterial culture from the liver of the lorikeet, which was also positive by real-time PCR.

@gm$ Fusobacterium nucleatum @/gm$, Rothia mucilaginosa, Streptococcus australis, and Lachnospiraceae bacterium oral taxon 096 were positive in DCHD vs. CHD, DCHD vs. @di$ DM @/di$, and CHD vs. NM but negative in @di$ DM @/di$ vs. NM (Fig. 2C). These species can serve as a distinctive microbial consortium associated with DCHD, and the presence of diabetes can further affect these microbiota (Fig. 2E). The abundance of @gm$ Fusobacterium nucleatum @/gm$ increased in the oral cavity of patients with DCHD, while the abundance of R.

@gm$ Fusobacterium nucleatum @/gm$, an anaerobic Gram-negative bacterium, located in the intermediate layers of mature subgingival biofilms, is associated with periodontitis and colorectal cancer. Histological studies have revealed that macrophages induced by @gm$ F. nucleatum @/gm$ aggravate the progression of @di$ colitis @/di$ and are also related with complications of pregnancy, the synthesis of LPS being important to be considered among its pathogenicity factors. Furthermore, it has been observed that @gm$ F. nucleatum @/gm$ shows a synergy with the presence of P. gingivalis favoring the loss of alveolar bone. Both microorganisms increased the gene expression of TLR2 and TLR4. However, when analyzing the relationship between periodontitis and arthritis in mice, in which a mixture of P. gingivalis, @gm$ F. nucleatum @/gm$ and Actinobacillus actinomycetemcomintans was inoculated, less loss of alveolar bone was observed than when mice were inoculated with P. gingivalis alone, and oral inoculation with @gm$ F. nucleatum @/gm$ or A.

@gm$ Gardnerella vaginalis @/gm$ and Atopobium vaginae are especially known to be associated with BV. Although BV is a benign pathology, we report a septic shock caused by @gm$ Gardnerella vaginalis @/gm$ and Atopobium vaginae after a total hysterectomy with adnexectomy due to @di$ leiomyosarcoma @/di$.

@gm$ Gardnerella vaginalis @/gm$ is an anaerobic, gram-variable bacterium primarily found in vaginal microflora of women. Previous reports of @gm$ G. vaginalis @/gm$ cultured in men are few and have primarily been limited to the gastrointestinal and genitourinary tract.2-4 Few reports of @gm$ G. vaginalis @/gm$ causing severe infections have been reported in the literature, including septicemia7 and two cases of @di$ perinephric abscess.8,9 @/di$ There has been one previously reported case of @gm$ G. vaginalis @/gm$ causing pulmonary complications that occurred in a male alcohol abuser. In our case review, we aim to demonstrate an unusual source of a pulmonary infection and highlight the importance of proper microbial isolation to guide treatment. Our patient is a young male who presented following multiple gunshot wounds including one to his head causing an intracranial hemorrhage, hydrocephalus, and a dural sinus thrombosis. His hospital course was complicated by a decline in neurological status treated with a craniotomy and external drain placement and multiple pulmonary infections. During his fever work-ups, he found to have @gm$ G. vaginalis @/gm$ on mini-bronchoalveolar lavage and was subsequently treated with metronidazole. After treating his G. vaginalis pneumonia and other infectious sources, namely Haemaphilus influenzae and coagulase-negative staphylococcus pneumonias, his fevers and leukocytosis resolved and he was successfully discharged to a rehabilitation facility for neurologic recovery. To our knowledge, this is the second reported case of @gm$ G. vaginalis @/gm$ isolated from a pulmonary culture and the first in a previously healthy, immunocompetent young male outside of the urinary tract.

@gm$ Haemophilus parainfluenzae @/gm$, which belongs to the HACEK (Haemophilus ssp, Actinobacillus actinomycetemcomitans, Cardiobacterium hominis, Eikenella corrodens, and Kingella kingae) group, is a rare cause of subacute endocarditis and may lead to ischemic stroke. A 65-year-old female patient previously diagnosed with rheumatic valve disease was submitted to surgical mitral valve repair in 1996. Physical examination did not reveal any murmurs; physical examination of the lungs and abdomen was normal. The patient was admitted to hospital with progressive dyspnea, dry cough, and fever. Transesophageal echocardiogram revealed an approximately 8-mm filamentous image with chaotic motion in the ventricular face of the anterior mitral valve leaflet compatible with vegetation. Treatment with ceftriaxone and gentamicin was initiated. @gm$ Haemophilus parainfluenzae @/gm$ grew in five blood culture samples. Along the hospital stay, the patient's level of consciousness decreased, and she was diagnosed with ischemic stroke of cardioembolic etiology. The patient developed @di$ septic shock @/di$ refractory to the prescribed treatment and died 12 days after admission. Even though the patient started being treated for endocarditis before the infectious agent was identified, the prompt use of antimicrobials hindered the growth of @gm$ Haemophilus parainfluenzae @/gm$ and made its isolation difficult.

@gm$ L. gasseri @/gm$ also has probiotic characteristics. Based on the results of other studies, it can be inferred that the changes in intestinal microbiota might be because of E. faecium, which is commonly used as a probiotic. E. faecium could significantly reduce the number of Clostridium spp. in feces as a result of oral feeding to 12 healthy house dogs. In another study, @di$ diarrhea @/di$ was significantly reduced in cats living in animal shelters by feeding E.

@gm$ L. johnsonii @/gm$ may be biologically active after heat treatment, although knowledge of the molecular mechanisms is lacking. Joo et al. observed that macrophages treated with LPS in the presence of HI-@gm$ L. johnsonii @/gm$ significantly decrease the productions of IL-6, IL-1beta, and TNF-alpha compared with LPS alone. Additionally, another report showed that heat killed @gm$ Lactobacillus @/gm$ paracacei KW3110 induces dectin-2 gene expression in macrophages and activates macrophages to produce IL-10, which may be related to the characteristic carbohydrate chain of L.actobacillus paracacei KW3110. Oral administration of HI-@gm$ L. johnsonii @/gm$ significantly inhibits the production of IL-1beta and TNF-alpha, and increases the production of IL-10 and CD206 in 2,3,6-trinitrobenzenesulfonic acid-induced @di$ colitis @/di$ mice by suppressing LPS-induced nuclear factor kappa-B activation. In our study, we found HI-@gm$ L. johnsonii @/gm$ treatment also significantly decreased the proportions of total macrophages and increased the proportions IL-10+ M2 macrophages in the liver. However, relatively little research has focused on @gm$ L. johnsonii @/gm$ cell membrane. We reason the cell surface architecture of @gm$ L. johnsonii @/gm$ may mediate toll-like receptor 2-dependent extracellular regulated protein kinases activation to alleviate SILI and regulate macrophages response. Further study will address whether the specific structure of @gm$ L. johnsonii @/gm$ cell membrane is potentially therapeutically useful for sepsis and whether the immune response is associated with this effect.

@gm$ L. lactis @/gm$ is a catalase-negative gram-positive bacterium that is used in the dairy industry as a starter in cheese fermentation. Because it rarely causes infectious disease in humans, there are only a few reports of @gm$ Lactococcus @/gm$-associated infection in immunocompromised hosts, such as patients with native valve endocarditis, osteomyelitis, @di$ spondylitis @/di$, and liver abscess. In addition, to date, only 4 cases of @gm$ Lactococcus @/gm$-associated PD peritonitis have been reported: L. cremoris-associated PD peritonitis in Belgium, @gm$ L. lactis @/gm$ in Turkey, L. cremoris in Canada, and L. garvieae in Taiwan. In Korea, consumption of dairy products has increased recently reflecting rising incomes and Westernized diets; therefore, there may be an increased risk of @gm$ Lactococcus @/gm$-associated infectious disease, especially in immune-deficient patients. In our case, the patient frequently ate and handled butter without washing his hands before dressing his exit site and handling the peritoneal dialysate. Therefore, contamination during exchange was a possible route of infection. Owing to the presence of both gram-negative and gram-positive organisms in this case, we also considered intra-abdominal disease and transluminal contamination. Although the abdominal computed tomography scan showed no obvious causes of the intra-abdominal lesions except peritonitis, invisible lesions such as micro-perforations are a possible source of transmission, because @gm$ Lactococcus @/gm$, along with other Enterobacteriaceae, are part of the normal gastrointestinal tract flora.

@gm$ Lactobacillus @/gm$ bacteria are widely known for their beneficial health effects and their use as probiotics. Despite several studies reporting a higher abundance of @gm$ Lactobacillus @/gm$ to be associated with diverse positive factors like sleep and self-judgment, no direct correlation of @gm$ Lactobacillus @/gm$ abundance and affective disorder could be identified. Family Streptococcaceae and genus Streptococcus showed a positive correlation with @di$ depression @/di$ and lower quality of life scores. For example, beta-hemolytic Streptococcus Group A infections are known to potentially cause Pediatric Autoimmune Neuropsychiatric Disorders (Associated with Streptococcal Infections, "PANDAS"), which are associated with alterations in the gut microbiome and the nervous system. Although not fully understood, it demonstrates that Streptococcus infections can lead to an autoimmune response, severe brain alterations, disturbed neurotransmitters, and can cause psychiatric symptoms like obsessive-compulsive disorder, tics, anxiety, and sometimes even @di$ depression @/di$. Of the included studies, four reported an elevation of Streptococcaceae (or OTUs within this family) and Streptococcus in MDD and BD. Additionally, investigating a large cohort, Valles-Colomer et al. found a negative association between Streptococcus and body pain, but no direct association with @di$ depression @/di$, maybe due to the cohort representing the general population and not being limited to specifically MDD or BD subjects.

@gm$ Lactobacillus @/gm$ is acidogenic bacteria that cause @di$ dental caries @/di$. Children and adults suffer from pain, structural damage to their teeth, and eventual tooth loss due to the loss of mineralized tissues. @gm$ Lactobacillus @/gm$ is the most common bacteria that cause periodontal diseases and cause inflammation, and infection. An arsenal of redox potentials is found in plant extracts. NPs with defined sizes can be produced by biogenic synthesis using phytochemical compounds as stabilizers. Propolis is used in traditional medicine for its biological properties. The antioxidative, anti-inflammatory, and antibacterial properties of propolis are noteworthy. Propolis exhibits antiproliferative and antitumor properties in vitro and in vivo. It depends on the region, climate, and extraction season. Because propolis contains polyphenolic acids, flavonoids, and terpenoids, it can produce gold NPs. The cost of manufacturing metallic NPs can be reduced by capping and reducing metallic NPs with biological components. Since they do not require excessive pressure or energy, they are environmentally friendly and energy-efficient. NPs can be manufactured from medicinal plants. Allium sativum, Aleo vera, and Punica granatum have been used to synthesize copper NPs. This research aimed to synthesize the CuO NPs using propolis extracts and evaluate their antibacterial and cytotoxicity on @gm$ Lactobacillus acidophilus @/gm$ and HEK-293 cells, respectively.

@gm$ Lactococcus lactis @/gm$ is a homofermentative Gram-positive bacterium used as a starter culture in a wide variety of fermented food products. Its small genome size, the availability of tightly regulated promoter systems, mild proteolytic activity and generally-regarded-as-safe status make it an ideal host for the production, secretion and delivery of peptides directly to the intestine. Recombinant interleukin 10-producing @gm$ L. lactis @/gm$ has been shown to protect against @di$ colitis @/di$ in mouse models and is now being tested in a phase 2a clinical trial in patients with Crohn's disease, indicating the potential of recombinant bacterial strains in the treatment of human disease.

@gm$ Lactococcus raffinolactis @/gm$ and its other members belong to the family Streptococcaceae, and they are used in different industries for meat preservation, starters, and flavoring purposes. There are many studies on the isolation and antimicrobial features of probiotic bacteria such as Lactobacillus and Lactococcus. However, few studies correlate the probiotic effect on neurological inflammation. Therefore, this study aims to focus on the probiotic potential of @gm$ Lactococcus raffinolactis @/gm$ and its role in the modulation of neuroinflammation. It has recently been reported that Lactococcus lactis displayed a significant positive impact in an LPS-induced depression-like model in mice, alleviated depressive and @di$ anxiety @/di$ symptoms in mice, attenuated acute psychological stress in healthy Japanese men, and prevented the migration of cells into the spinal cord in experimental autoimmune encephalomyelitis.

@gm$ Legionella @/gm$ is a well-known cause of @di$ pneumonia @/di$. Extrapulmonary manifestations of Legionnaires' disease include myocarditis, neurological involvement (acute disseminated encephalomyelitis), and multiorgan failure. Legionnaires' disease has been reported together with several types of skin lesions such as maculopapular rash, petechial rash, erythema with focal blister, cellulitis, pustules, abscesses, and subcutaneous masses. Various species of @gm$ Legionella @/gm$, including L. pneumophila, L. micdadei, L. cincinnatiensis, L. maceachernii, and L. feeleii, cause skin/soft tissue infection, mostly among immunocompromised patients with @di$ pneumonia @/di$. Primary cutaneous infection is a rare distinctive feature of direct inoculation of @gm$ Legionella @/gm$ into skin and soft tissue, which occurs as cellulitis necrotizing fasciitis, as a postoperative complication. The diagnosis of legionellosis can be challenging in the absence of @di$ pneumonia @/di$. To the best of our knowledge, this is the first description of panniculitis due to @gm$ Legionella @/gm$.

@gm$ Legionella pneumophila @/gm$ is a Gram-negative bacterium found in natural and man-made water systems where it replicates within amoebas and ciliates. In humans, once inside the lungs, @gm$ L. pneumophila @/gm$ replicates in alveolar macrophages and causes Legionnaires' disease, a severe @di$ pneumonia @/di$. The Icm/Dot type IVb secretion system is a major virulence factor required for intracellular multiplication. The Icm/Dot system allows the secretion of effectors into the cytoplasm of the host cell. These effectors modify host cell vesicular trafficking and prevent maturation of the phagosome. The innate immune response is crucial in restricting @gm$ L. pneumophila @/gm$ proliferation. TNF-alpha is one of the major cytokines involved in this process as it renders macrophages more resistant to L. pneumophila infection and induces apoptosis of @gm$ L. pneumophila @/gm$-infected macrophages. Tail-specific proteases (Tsp) are involved in tolerating thermal stress and in virulence. We have previously characterized the Tsp encoded by @gm$ L. pneumophila @/gm$, showing that it is important for surviving thermal stress and for infection of amoeba when a temperature change occurs during infection.

@gm$ Legionella pneumophila @/gm$ is a motile gram-negative bacterium that is the cause of a severe form of @di$ pneumonia @/di$ called Legionnaires' disease. Virulence of @gm$ Legionella @/gm$ depends on its capacity to replicate inside host macrophages. @gm$ Legionella @/gm$ utilizes a type IV secretion system (encoded by the dot/icm genes) to inject effector proteins into the cytosol of host cells. The secreted effector proteins (more than 30 of which have now been identified) direct the host cell to create a unique intracellular vacuole in which @gm$ Legionella @/gm$ can thrive and multiply.

@gm$ Legionella pneumophila @/gm$, which causes community-acquired pneumonia that requires hospitalization, is an opportunistic pathogen that is omnipresent in aquatic environments in which it replicates in free-living amoebae. @gm$ L. pneumophila @/gm$ pneumonia is strongly associated with high morbidity. Moreover, legionellosis is consistently reported as one of the top three most identified respiratory pathogens in community-acquired pneumonia, along with the hospital-acquired @di$ pneumonia @/di$.

@gm$ Leuconostoc citreum @/gm$ are Gram-positive, catalase-negative cocci, that belong to the family Lactobacillaceae. They are primarily known to be resistant to glycopeptides including vancomycin. The @gm$ Leuconostoc @/gm$ species have been recently identified to cause serious infections, including bacteremia, urinary tract infections, pneumonia, meningitis, endocarditis, liver and lung abscesses, @di$ peritonitis @/di$, and intra-abdominal infections. Reported cases of infections caused by the @gm$ Leuconostoc @/gm$ species are limited in the literature.

@gm$ Leuconostoc citreum @/gm$ are Gram-positive, catalase-negative cocci, that belong to the family Lactobacillaceae. They are primarily known to be resistant to glycopeptides including vancomycin. The Leuconostoc species have been recently identified to cause serious infections, including @di$ bacteremia @/di$, urinary tract infections, pneumonia, meningitis, endocarditis, liver and lung abscesses, peritonitis, and intra-abdominal infections.
