@gm$ M. chelonae @/gm$ can cause lung disease, local cutaneous disease, @di$ osteomyelitis @/di$, joint infections and ocular disease.

@gm$ M. elsdenii @/gm$, which is capable of utilizing lactic acid in the rumen, is believed to be responsible for rumen health maintenace. In the present study, although @gm$ M. elsdenii @/gm$ administration did not significantly affect rumen score and liver score, it reduced the risk of livestock experiencing @di$ liver abscess @/di$ and the incidence of diarrhoea and bloat. This reduced risk of @di$ liver abscess @/di$ reflects a mutually beneficial rumen fermentation between @gm$ M. elsdenii @/gm$ and rumen microbes. Furthermore, Miller et al stated that livestock given commercial probiotic @gm$ M. elsdenii @/gm$ Lacticpro experienced a decrease in the incidence and severity of @di$ liver abscess @/di$, which indicated that @gm$ M. elsdenii @/gm$ was effective in preventing acidosis in cattle. Meanwhile, the number of cattle that experienced diarrhoea and bloat were lower following the @gm$ M. elsdenii @/gm$ supplementation. Administration of @gm$ M. elsdenii @/gm$ strain NCIMB 41125 was able to reduce morbidity or livestock experiencing health problems.

@gm$ M. kansasii @/gm$ belongs to the group photochromogens, and is a slow-growing acid-fast bacillus, being the second most common NTM infection in the United States after Mycobacterium avium complex (MAC). These organisms are generally isolated from treated water sources such as tap water, swimming pools and fish tanks, but have also been isolated from natural water sources as well. Cases in the US have most commonly been encountered in the southern and central regions of the country. The infection is acquired through the aerosol route, whereas most other NTM have also been reported to be acquired through inoculation or ingestion as well. Infections by @gm$ M. kansasii @/gm$ have been associated with heavy smoking and alcohol abuse. Other risk factors include @di$ COPD @/di$, previous gastrectomy, immunocompromised status, or a history of prior pulmonary TB. In patients with HIV, the incidence of M. kansasii infection rises with a CD4 count of <50/mm3. Clinically, @gm$ M. kansasii @/gm$ can affect multiple organs and systems, either individually or with disseminated disease. Pulmonary disease is the most common presentation of M. kansasii infection. It is usually seen in the form of chronic pulmonary cavitary lesions typically affecting the upper lobes of the lungs. Symptoms of pulmonary @gm$ M. kansasii @/gm$ typically resembles that of tuberculosis, often leading to misdiagnosis.
@gm$ Methanomassiliicoccus intestinalis @/gm$. Methanogens are emerging pathogens associated with @di$ brain and muscular abscesses @/di$.

@gm$ Methanomassiliicoccus intestinalis @/gm$. Methanogens are emerging pathogens associated with brain and muscular abscesses. They have been implicated in dysbiosis of the oral microbiota, @di$ periodontitis @/di$ and peri-implantitis.

@gm$ Methanomassiliicoccus intestinalis @/gm$. Methanogens are emerging pathogens associated with brain and muscular abscesses. They have been implicated in dysbiosis of the oral microbiota, periodontitis and @di$ peri-implantitis @/di$.

@gm$ Methanomassiliicoccus intestinalis @/gm$. Methanogens are emerging pathogens associated with brain and muscular abscesses. They have been implicated in dysbiosis of the oral microbiota, periodontitis and peri-implantitis. They have also been associated with dysbiosis of the digestive tract microbiota linked to metabolic disorders (@di$ anorexia @/di$, malnutrition and obesity) and with lesions of the digestive tract (colon cancer).

@gm$ Methanomassiliicoccus intestinalis @/gm$. Methanogens are emerging pathogens associated with brain and muscular abscesses. They have been implicated in dysbiosis of the oral microbiota, periodontitis and peri-implantitis. They have also been associated with dysbiosis of the digestive tract microbiota linked to metabolic disorders (anorexia, malnutrition and @di$ obesity @/di$) and with lesions of the digestive tract (colon cancer).

@gm$ Mycobacterium marinum @/gm$ is a waterborne @gm$ mycobacterium @/gm$ that commonly infects fish and amphibians worldwide, but transmission to humans can occasionally occur, typically as a granulomatous skin infection following minor hand trauma. Infection involving the lungs is very rare. We herein describe a case of @gm$ M. marinum @/gm$-associated pneumonia and pneumothorax. In August 2008, an 81-year-old man was admitted to a hospital for detailed examination of weight loss and an abnormal shadow on chest imaging. Based on a sputum test, nontuberculous mycobacteriosis caused by @gm$ M. marinum @/gm$ was diagnosed. At that time, the blood chemistry revealed no respiratory symptoms or inflammatory findings, and the patient was treated on an outpatient basis with erythromycin and an expectorant. In late November 2008, sputum and coughing were observed. Furthermore, the patient developed a @di$ fever @/di$ and chest pain that increased while breathing and he visited the emergency outpatient unit of our hospital on December 1. Hypoxemia, bilateral pneumonia, and right pneumothorax were observed, and a chest tube was inserted into the right thoracic cavity. Results of an acid-fast bacteria smear from the sputum and pleural effusion were positive, and @gm$ M. marinum @/gm$ was identified on culture. The patient was diagnosed as having a lung infection complicated by pneumothorax caused by @gm$ M. marinum @/gm$.

@gm$ Mycobacterium tuberculosis @/gm$ (MTB) is a pathogen that infects and kills millions yearly. The @gm$ mycobacterium @/gm$'s cell wall glycolipid trehalose 6,6'-dimycolate (TDM) has been used historically to model MTB induced inflammation and granuloma formation. Alterations to the model can significantly influence the induced pathology. One such method incorporates intraperitoneal pre-exposure, after which the intravenous injection of TDM generates pathological damage effectively mimicking the @di$ hypercoagulation @/di$, thrombus formation, and tissue remodeling apparent in lungs of infected individuals. The purpose of these experiments is to examine the histological inflammation involved in the TDM mouse model that induces development of the hemorrhagic response. TDM induced lungs of C57BL/6 mice to undergo granulomatous inflammation. Further histological examination of the peak response demonstrated tissue remodeling consistent with @di$ hypercoagulation @/di$. The observed vascular occlusion indicates that obstruction likely occurs due to subendothelial localized activity leading to restriction of blood vessel lumens. Trichrome staining revealed that associated damage in the @di$ hypercoagulation @/di$ model is consistent with intra endothelial cell accumulation of innate cells, bordered by collagen deposition in the underlying parenchyma. Overall, the @di$ hypercoagulation @/di$ model represents a comparative pathological instrument for understanding mechanisms underlying development of hemorrhage and vascular occlusion seen during MTB infection.

@gm$ Ornithobacterium rhinotracheale @/gm$ appears to have been the cause of respiratory disease in poultry since at least 1981, although its biochemical characteristics and phylogenetic position were not determined until the early 1990's. It is a global pathogen and has been isolated not only from turkeys and chickens but also a variety of other domesticated and wild birds, including chukar partridges, ducks, geese, guinea fowl, gulls, ostriches, partridges, pheasants, pigeons, quail, rooks, and falcons. A typing scheme based on the reaction of monospecific antisera with heat-extracted antigens has so far discriminated 18 serotypes of @gm$ O. rhinotracheale @/gm$, designated as A through R, although not all isolates are typeable. The most common clinical signs of disease related to @gm$ O. rhinotracheale @/gm$ are pneumonia, tracheitis, airsacculitis, @di$ sinusitis @/di$, and pericarditis.
@gm$ Ornithobacterium rhinotracheale @/gm$(ORT) causes @di$ respiratory infections @/di$, such as airsacculitis and pneumonia, in birds all over the world.

@gm$ Oscillibacter valericigenes @/gm$ produces valeric acid, an SCFA. Valeric acid has been reported to have an inhibitory effect on histone deacetylase (HDAC) isoforms implicated in a variety of disorders such as cancer, colitis, and @di$ cardiovascular and neurodegenerative diseases @/di$. In this study, @gm$ O. valericigenes @/gm$ showed a positive relationship with fiber consumption (Table 3).

@gm$ Oxalobacter formigenes @/gm$ is an anaerobic, commensal bacteria of the human colon that utilizes oxalate as its sole energy source. Controlled diet studies have shown that colonized individuals, estimated between 38-77% of the world's population, excrete significantly less oxalate than non-colonized individuals. Furthermore, lack of @gm$ O. formigenes @/gm$ colonization has been demonstrated to be a risk factor for both @di$ hyperoxaluria @/di$ and recurrent calcium oxalate stone disease but has not been studied as a therapy in the bariatric population. Our group has previously reported elevations in fecal fat and urinary oxalate in an obese rodent model of RYGB. We hypothesized that @gm$ O. formigenes @/gm$ colonization could reverse RYGB-associated @di$ hyperoxaluria @/di$ and examined the effect of @gm$ O. formigenes @/gm$ colonization on urinary oxalate excretion and intestinal oxalate transport in this established hyperoxaluric model.

@gm$ P. mendocina @/gm$ can infect both immunocompromised and immunocompetent hosts. Most of the reported @gm$ P. mendocina @/gm$-related infections occurred in immunocompetent adults with several comorbidities, as shown in Table 4. A few cases were reported in immunocompromised adults. Gani et al. reported bacteremia in a patient with resistant HIV/AIDS. Huang et al. reported meningitis in a patient with a history of diabetes mellitus type 2 and buccal cancer. Gupta et al. previously reported a wound infection in a patient with diabetes mellitus type 2 and a prolonged history of asthma and intermittent corticosteroid use. Our patient had a 10-year history of prostate cancer with bone metastases and was receiving treatment with abiraterone 1000 mg daily with an injection every three months and prednisone 5 mg daily. His immune system might be compromised due to his prostate cancer and treatment. It can be argued that @gm$ P. mendocina @/gm$ caused an opportunistic @di$ urinary tract infection @/di$ in our immunocompromised patient.

@gm$ P. micra @/gm$ is a fastidious, anaerobic, gram-positive coccus that is found in healthy human oral and gastrointestinal flora. Previous studies have reported that @gm$ P. micra @/gm$ is involved in @di$ lung abscesses @/di$, iliopsoas abscesses, gastric carcinogenesis and infections of the periodontal area, soft tissue, bone and joints. Currently, based on metagenomic or 16S RNA sequencing analysis, numerous studies have revealed the relationship between @gm$ P. micra @/gm$ and CRC. By analyzing the 16S rRNA gene sequence data of 509 fecal samples from ethnically different cohorts, including those from China and Austria, Yu et al observed that the detection rate and abundance of @gm$ P. micra @/gm$ were significantly higher in patients with CRC compared with controls, and these results were further validated using quantitative PCR (qPCR) in 309 subjects. By analyzing the metagenomics sequencing results from 778 (including 386 samples from patients with CRC and 392 controls) and 969 (meta-analysis of five publicly available databases and two new cohorts with validation of the findings of two additional cohorts) stool samples, two research groups discovered that CRC-related microbial markers, including @gm$ P. micra @/gm$, could be consistently detected among different populations, regardless of the detection techniques, diet, geographical environment, genetics and other factors. These results demonstrate that @gm$ P. micra @/gm$ has an important relationship with CRC, and may be involved in the development of CRC.

@gm$ P. micra @/gm$ is an anaerobic Gram-positive coccus and its diagnosis is often challenging because it is difficult to culture. Furthermore, its pathogenicity has not been studied extensively. A previous study reported that the strong proteolytic activity of @gm$ P. micra @/gm$ could be important in @di$ abscess @/di$ development. @gm$ P. micra @/gm$ forms hydrogen sulfide, which is cytotoxic, from glutathione, a tripeptide involved in intracellular defense against reactive oxygen metabolites.

@gm$ P. pentosaceus @/gm$ converts food into nutrients and promote mineral utilization. To the best of our knowledge, phytic acid is harmful to mineral bioavailability. Moreover, sourdough-derived @gm$ P. pentosaceus @/gm$ B3 and B11 and chicken intestine-derived @gm$ P. pentosaceus @/gm$ CFR R38 and R35 were able to degrade phytate and promote mineral bioavailability. Similarly, from among 60 strains of LAB from cereal- and pulse-based fermented mixtures, @gm$ P. pentosaceus @/gm$ CFR R123 not only significantly improved the availability of calcium but also reduced cholesterol and beta-galactosidase levels. @gm$ P. pentosaceus @/gm$ CFR R123 degraded 43% of phytate in one hour in an experiment designed by Raghavendra et al.. These phytate-degrading @gm$ P. pentosaceus @/gm$ have potential as nutritive food additives. In the model of grass carp sausages, @gm$ P. pentosaceus @/gm$ GY23 showed a proteolytic profile that was different from that of other LAB. With high proteolysis ability, Malaysian food-derived @gm$ P. pentosaceus @/gm$ UP-2 could produce 15 extracellular amino acids (AAs) for body nutrition or biological functions. Isolated from tempeh-fermented soybean cake, @gm$ P. pentosaceus @/gm$ TL-3 was confirmed to have the highest threonine and methionine production among LAB. gamma-Aminobutyric acid (GABA) is an amino acid that has been reported to ameliorate diabetes, @di$ hypertension @/di$, and even cancer development. There are several kinds of LAB that produce GABA, and @gm$ P. pentosaceus @/gm$ HN8, which was collected from Thai fermented pork sausage, is one such LAB. Moreover, one strain of @gm$ P. pentosaceus @/gm$ in Assam produced dextran, which is nonpoisonous and bioactive.

@gm$ Parvimonas micra @/gm$ (@gm$ P. micra @/gm$) is a member of GPAC normally found in the oral cavity, respiratory system, gastrointestinal tract (GIT), and the female genitourinary tract. Originally known as @gm$ Peptostreptococcus micros @/gm$, the organism was reclassified as @gm$ P. micra @/gm$ in 2006. @gm$ P. micra @/gm$ is one of the bacterial species most frequently isolated from infected root canals of teeth with chronic apical periodontitis. @gm$ P. micra @/gm$ has also been implicated in meningitis, @di$ cervical and brain abscess @/di$, infective endocarditis (IE), and spondylodiscitis. Recently, Badri et al. demonstrated that @gm$ P. micra @/gm$ was one of the most commonly isolated GPAC species and characteristics of Parvimonas spp. bacteremia (mostly @gm$ P. micra @/gm$) were discussed. However, due to historical difficulties with laboratory identification, there is a paucity of published data about the clinical characteristics or mortality due to bloodstream infection by @gm$ P. micra @/gm$.

@gm$ Parvimonas micra @/gm$ is a Gram-positive obligate anaerobe from the largely uncharacterized Tissierellia class of the Firmicutes phylum. Initially grouped within the Peptostreptococcus genus, a taxonomic reclassification revealed its distinction within the Firmicutes. @gm$ P. micra @/gm$ is a common constituent of the microbiomes from multiple mucosal sites in the body, including the oral cavity, gastrointestinal tract, respiratory system, and female urogenital tract. Epidemiological studies implicate @gm$ P. micra @/gm$ as a major human pathobiont. For example, it is both an exceptionally common and highly enriched species in numerous studies of different mucosal inflammatory diseases. In addition, @gm$ P. micra @/gm$ is among the most common sources of Gram-positive anaerobic cocci (GPAC) sepsis. It is also one of the most abundant species in numerous types of systemic @di$ abscesses @/di$, and it exhibits a surprisingly strong association with a variety of malignant tumors. In fact, @gm$ P. micra @/gm$ has even been proposed as a discriminating biomarker for colorectal cancer, gastric cancer, and oral cancer. In the oral cavity, @gm$ P. micra @/gm$ exists as a low-abundance species during oral health but is highly enriched in periodontitis lesions and infected root canals and is especially prevalent in polymicrobial @di$ odontogenic abscesses @/di$.

@gm$ Parvimonas micra @/gm$ is a known commensal bacterium of the human oral flora and gastrointestinal tract. It is an obligate anaerobe, identified in 1933 as @gm$ Peptostreptococcus micros @/gm$. It was reclassified in 1999 as Mircomonas micros, and then in 2006 as @gm$ P. micra @/gm$. @di$ Infections @/di$ with @gm$ P. micra @/gm$ outside of the oral cavity are uncommon. Some case reports have isolated @gm$ P. micra @/gm$ from spinal abscesses, while others have found @gm$ P. micra @/gm$ as causative agents of meningitis, septic arthritis, chest wall abscess, spondylodiscitis, empyema, endocarditis, and brain abscess. A thorough literature search revealed no reports of hepatic infections with @gm$ P. micra @/gm$ in current literature.

@gm$ Pediococcus pentosaceus @/gm$ is another probiotic species that belongs to family Lactobacillaceae. Several strains of @gm$ P. pentosaceus @/gm$ has been extensively used for food preservation and also they displayed remarkable probiotic properties including an antimicrobial activity and regulation of @di$ inflammation @/di$ in animals.
@gm$ Phascolarctobacterium succinatutens @/gm$ synthesizes propionate from sugars and protects the colonic mucosa, reduces the effects of @di$ colitis @/di$, and increases the risk of colon cancer.

@gm$ Plesiomonas shigelloides @/gm$ is a facultative, anaerobic, gram-negative rod that was recently classified in the family Enterobacteriaceae and is the only oxidase-positive member of this family. Similar to many Enterobacteriaceae species, @gm$ P. shigelloides @/gm$ is found in a wide range of hosts, including cats, cows, dogs, pigs, and monkeys. In humans, @gm$ P. shigelloides @/gm$ has been implicated in gastrointestinal infections, and the organism has also been shown to cause @di$ bacteremia @/di$, sepsis, meningitis, pneumonia, osteomyelitis, keratitis, and other non-diarrheal diseases. In a recent extensive review of illnesses caused by @gm$ P. shigelloides @/gm$, little information was presented about the prevalence of P. shigelloides infections in China. We recently observed an association between @gm$ P. shigelloides @/gm$ and infections involving gastroenteritis and extra-intestinal illnesses. Here, we provide a local perspective on the diseases caused by @gm$ P. shigelloides @/gm$ in southeast China.

@gm$ Plesiomonas shigelloides @/gm$ is a facultatively anaerobic, gram-negative, rod-shaped bacterium in the family Enterobacteriaceae, which also contains Escherichia, Shigella, Salmonella, and Klebsiella. It has been shown to cause gastroenteritis and diarrhea; severe disease can manifest as invasive colitis similar to shigellosis or voluminous secretory diarrhea. Symptoms include fever, abdominal pain, @di$ nausea @/di$, vomiting, watery or bloody diarrhea, and dehydration. The pathophysiology of infection with @gm$ P. shigelloides @/gm$ remains unknown, although cytotoxin and enterotoxin-mediated damage has been proposed, and is still under investigation. A case of PMC, presenting with six months of bloody diarrhea, and attributed to @gm$ P. shigelloides @/gm$ has been reported; the patient was treated with oral tetracycline after multiple positive stool cultures and improved rapidly.

@gm$ Plesiomonas shigelloides @/gm$ is an oxidase-positive, anaerobic gram negative bacillus bacteria of the Enterobacteriaceae family which normally reside in soil and fresh water environments including the Great Lakes. @gm$ P. shigelloides @/gm$ is also distributed among warm- and cold-blooded animals like dogs and seafood. Its method of @di$ infection @/di$ is contamination of the gastrointestinal tract via consumption of raw fish or water-contaminated foods.

@gm$ Prevotella @/gm$, previously classified in the genus Bacteroides, was a genus of an obligate anaerobic gram-negative rod-shape bacterium. They are classified as "black pigmented bacteria" as they form shiny and smooth colonies with grey, light brown or black color on blood agar plate. Although they generally have a limited ability to ferment amino acid and require hemin and menadione to grow, @gm$ Prevotella @/gm$ is a versatile genus which has been observed in various niches, such as oral cavity, upper respiratory tract, urogenital tract, rumen and human feces. Many @gm$ Prevotella @/gm$ taxa from oral cavity are potential/opportunistic pathogens. Gomes et al have shown that @gm$ Prevotella @/gm$ spp is associated with pain and swelling and 'wet' canal of @di$ oral diseases @/di$. Besides, Prevotella intermdedia, Prevotella dentalis, @gm$ Prevotella denticola @/gm$, Prevotella meleninogenica are known to be pathogenic under a wide range of situations and invade into the host tissues.

@gm$ Pseudomonas aeruginosa @/gm$ is a widespread Gram-negative water and soil bacterium, which is, in addition, one of the most important opportunistic human pathogens causing severe infections in immunocompromised persons, such as burn wound, catheter and urinary tract infections or chronic pneumonia in @di$ cystic fibrosis @/di$ (CF) patients. Due to a large arsenal of intrinsic resistance mechanisms such as a low outer membrane permeability, the expression of antibiotic cleaving enzymes, and the existence of multidrug efflux pump systems, @gm$ P. aeruginosa @/gm$ is inherently resistant to various commonly used antibiotics.

@gm$ Pseudomonas fulva @/gm$ was first described in 1963 and belongs to fluorescent group of Pseudomonas. This microorganism is mainly recovered from rice seed samples, rice, and petroleum fields and oil brine and from the gills of some mollusks. These bacilli are an uncommon pseudomonal opportunistic pathogen causing very rare infection in human population. Until now, only two infections have been documented in humans: an isolate causing @di$ meningitis @/di$ in a 2-year-old girl after placement of a cerebral shunt system and an isolate causing bacteremia in a 56-year-old man who suffered a trauma. In our knowledge, we are describing the third case of infection by @gm$ P. fulva @/gm$ in a patient with a trauma due to a traffic accident.

@gm$ Pseudomonas mendocina @/gm$ is a gram-negative, aerobic, rod-shaped bacterium that rarely causes disease in humans. Documented infections can be severe with varying etiologies, often requiring intensive care. We describe a rare case of bacteremia with @gm$ P. mendocina @/gm$ in an elderly male, with a comprehensive review of the literature. An 81-year-old Caucasian male presented with bilateral lower leg erythema and drainage but was afebrile. His past medical history included atrial fibrillation, chronic kidney disease, and congestive heart failure. Labs showed @di$ leukocytosis @/di$ and a blood culture was obtained revealing @gm$ Pseudomonas mendocina @/gm$. The pathogen was susceptible to all antibiotics tested and he was successfully treated on cefepime inpatient and a two-week course of ciprofloxacin on discharge. Our case and literature review presents a successful treatment of a rare cause of bacteremia likely stemming from a soft tissue nidus. @gm$ P. mendocina @/gm$ has a favorable susceptibility profile and the antibiotics preferred differ from Pseudomonas aeruginosa, a more common pathogen.

@gm$ R. hominis @/gm$ is a representative Roseburia species. Modification in Roseburia abundance may affect various metabolic pathways and is associated with several diseases, including IBS, ulcerative colitis, @di$ obesity @/di$, type 2 diabetes, nervous system disorders, and allergies. Diets that are high in fermentable carbohydrates increase the relative abundance of Roseburia, which are capable of degrading polysaccharides, oligosaccharides, and sugars, indicating that fermentable carbohydrates might elevate the intestinal melatonin through increasing the abundance of Roseburia. Roseburia is characterized by SCFAs production, which can affect the intestinal epithelial barrier and regulate the function of innate immune cells through anti-inflammatory properties. Our previous study suggested that gavage of @gm$ R. hominis @/gm$ prevented stressed rats from developing visceral hypersensitivity and increased the propionate and butyrate levels in cecal contents. In this study, SCFAs levels were measured in the intestinal contents after @gm$ R. hominis @/gm$ treatment; thus, we found that propionate and butyrate levels significantly increased in both the cecum and colon (Figure 1).

@gm$ Raoultella ornithinolytica @/gm$ is a gram-negative, capsulate, aerobic, and nonmotile bacterium belonging to the family Enterobacteriacae. Three species of @gm$ Raoultella @/gm$, initially classified as Klebsiella, exist, R. electrica, R. planticola, and R. terrigena. These bacteria have been isolated from aquatic environments, fish, and ticks, where it can produce histamine because of histidine decarboxylase enzyme and can contaminate food, especially not well conserved fish and pork. Histamine toxicity produces symptoms that include flushing of skin, headache, @di$ pruritus @/di$, and abdominal cramping. This rare but emergent bacterium can cause a wide spectrum of clinical manifestations. For instance, human infections caused by @gm$ R. ornithinolytica @/gm$ are rare but can be responsible for bacteraemia, especially in patient with malignancies and immunodeficiencies. Furthermore, @gm$ R. ornithinolytica @/gm$ is responsible for urinary, bile tract, tracheal, bronchial, and lungs infections in patients with immunodeficiency. The majority of cases reported in the literature are community acquired infections, especially nosocomial. Neonatal sepsis is rare; however, it can be severe if not treated, as well as septic arthritis of the temporomandibular joint. In a case report after an early but temporary response to the antibiotic therapy, this bacterium leads to a complete demolition of the articulation. @gm$ R. ornithinolytica @/gm$ not only expresses beta-lactamase, which provides resistance to commonly used beta-lactam antibiotics but can also acquire genes for multi-drug resistance.

@gm$ Raoultella ornithinolytica @/gm$ is one of the three species of @gm$ Raoultella @/gm$. The present case report describes a two-year-old child who had complaints of discomfort and @di$ fever @/di$, and @gm$ Raoultella ornithinolytica @/gm$ in his urinary culture.

@gm$ Raoultella ornithinolytica @/gm$ was previously considered to be a rare opportunistic pathogen, which has not attracted enough attention from pediatricians. Currently, there are only few reports on children infected with @gm$ R. ornithinolytica @/gm$ all over the world, and none of the articles have ever provided a summary of the clinical characteristics of children infected with @gm$ R. ornithinolytica @/gm$. In our study, we reported five cases from an 1800-bed teaching hospital in southwest China, which is the largest number of children identified with @gm$ R. ornithinolytica @/gm$ to date. For the first time, together with the nine cases of @gm$ R. ornithinolytica @/gm$ reported by others, we have summarized the clinical characteristics of the 14 cases infected with the bacteria in children. Unlike adults, children are mainly infected with @gm$ R. ornithinolytica @/gm$ through the blood stream rather than biliary, respiratory, or urinary tracts. Secondly, most of the newborns infected with @gm$ R. ornithinolytica @/gm$ also develop @di$ skin flushing @/di$ and systemic erythema, mainly due to the presence of histamine-like substances in @gm$ R. ornithinolytica @/gm$.
@gm$ Roseburia faecis @/gm$ is a butyrate producer whose abundance has been related to weight loss and a reduced @di$ glucose intolerance @/di$ in mice.

@gm$ S. anginosus @/gm$ is a pathogenic species, the predominant microorganism in patients with @di$ aerobic vaginitis @/di$. Successful binding of these bacteria to extracellular matrix proteins, like fibronectin, fibrinogen and laminin plays an important role in their pathogenesis. The sag haemolysin of @gm$ S. anginosus @/gm$ has been described to initiate vaginal epithelial cell lysis.

@gm$ S. dysenteriae @/gm$ is a normal microflora of the human gastrointestinal system; however, it is considered one of the most important public health concerns, and a major cause of bloody diarrhoea and HUS (@gm$ S. dysenteriae @/gm$ type 1) in humans. The serotype 1 of this organism is closely related to Escherichia coli serotype O157: H7, regarding the fact that both of these organisms can secret Stxs. Foodborne outbreaks caused by @gm$ S. dysenteriae @/gm$ type 1 are highly associated with the consumption of undercooked processed foods and vegetable salads. HUS is the only disease caused by S. dysenteriae type 1 infection, and the typical symptoms of this disease are @di$ renal failure @/di$, thrombocytopenia and microangiopathic haemolytic anaemia. The fatality rate of this disease is 35%. @gm$ S. dysenteriae @/gm$ type 1 adheres to the human colonic mucin and attaches to the epithelial cells by using the same mechanisms and virulence factor genes employed by other species. After attachment and adherence, Stxs are secreted by this organism. In addition to the presence of Stxs encoding genes, there are some minor differences between the virulence factors of @gm$ S. dysenteriae @/gm$ type 1 and other species of Shigella bacteria. @gm$ S. dysenteriae @/gm$ type 1 uses type 2 secretion system (T2SS) as an effector delivery system to inject protein effectors into the host cell. This needle-like structure is encoded and expressed by gsp (A-O) genes in @gm$ S. dysenteriae @/gm$ type 1. @gm$ S. dysenteriae @/gm$ type 1 also uses a specific heme uptake system as a protective virulence factor encoded by Shu genes. This mechanism mediates the direct binding of heme-containing proteins and the secretion of hemophores to provide iron for the organism during the pathogenesis and survival processes. This mechanism also protects the DNA of @gm$ S. dysenteriae @/gm$ type 1 from heme-mediated oxidative damage.

@gm$ S. mutans @/gm$ will infect the hard tissues of the teeth by fermentation and result in acid products. @gm$ S. mutans @/gm$ have some characteristics such as the ability to attach to the enamel surface, produce metabolicity, and the ability to form biofilms producing extracellular polysaccharides substabce (EPS) and these properties support the occurrence of @di$ dental caries @/di$.

@gm$ Salmonella @/gm$ bacteriuria is rare and requires a high index of suspicion for diagnosis. Prolonged shedding of @gm$ Salmonella @/gm$ in the urine can be seen after a @di$ urinary tract infection @/di$ (@di$ UTI @/di$) in patients with nephrolithiasis or urinary tract abnormalities, mandating long-term antibiotic therapy with a surgical opinion for source control.

@gm$ Salmonella @/gm$ species: A total of 19/260 (7.3%) @gm$ Salmonella @/gm$ species were isolated from children with @di$ diarrhoea @/di$. Of these, 2(10.5%) Salmonella typhi, 3(15.8%) @gm$ Salmonella paratyphi A @/gm$ and 14(73.7%) @gm$ Salmonella @/gm$ species were isolated.

@gm$ Salmonella enterica serovar Choleraesuis @/gm$ (S. Choleraesuis) mainly causes swine paratyphoid in weaners younger than 4 months old, and can also cause food-borne diseases in humans. Septicemia is the typical acute clinical syndrome leading to death of piglets. However, most infected animals develop chronic infections characterized by @di$ wasting syndromes @/di$, such as malaise, anorexia, pyrexia, dyspnea, and pneumonia.

@gm$ Salmonella enterica serovar Choleraesuis @/gm$ (S. Choleraesuis) mainly causes swine paratyphoid in weaners younger than 4 months old, and can also cause food-borne diseases in humans. Septicemia is the typical acute clinical syndrome leading to death of piglets. However, most infected animals develop chronic infections characterized by wasting syndromes, such as malaise, @di$ anorexia @/di$, pyrexia, dyspnea, and pneumonia.

@gm$ Salmonella enterica serovar Choleraesuis @/gm$ (S. Choleraesuis), a highly invasive serovar among non-typhoidal Salmonella, usually causes @di$ sepsis @/di$ or extra-intestinal focal infections in humans.

@gm$ Salmonella enterica serovar Choleraesuis @/gm$ is a facultative intracellular pathogen capable of infecting and replicating monocytes and macrophages. In swine, S. Choleraesuis invades the intestinal epithelium, produces enterocolitis, and colonizes the ileocecal lymph nodes (ICLN) and has the unique ability to disseminate to systemic sites, causing sepsis. A frequently affected organ is the lung, where the blood-borne infection with Salmonella manifests as interstitial pneumonia. Notably, in field cases, coinfection of swine with S. Choleraesuis and porcine reproductive and respiratory syndrome virus (PRRSV) has been associated with more severe disease, including septicemic salmonellosis and severe @di$ pneumonia @/di$.

@gm$ Salmonella enterica serovar Choleraesuis @/gm$ is an enteric pathogen of swine, producing septicemia, @di$ enterocolitis @/di$, pneumonia, and hepatitis. The initial molecular events at the site of Salmonella infection are hypothesized to be critical in the initiation of innate and adaptive immune responses; however, the acute immune response elicited by porcine intestinal tissues is not well understood. To address this need, we employed explants of jejunal Peyer's patch (JPP) mucosa from pigs to examine @gm$ Salmonella @/gm$-induced immune responses under controlled conditions as well as to overcome limitations of whole animal approaches. JPP explants mounted in Ussing chambers maintained normal histological structure for 2 h and stable short-circuit current and electrical conductance for 2.5 h. After ex vivo luminal exposure to Salmonella serovar Choleraesuis, JPP responded with an increase in mRNA expression of IL-1beta and IL-8, but not TNFalpha. Increased IL-1beta and IL-8 expression were dependent on efficient @gm$ Salmonella @/gm$ adhesion and internalization, whereas mutant @gm$ Salmonella @/gm$ did not induce inflammatory cytokine expression. Commensal enteric bacteria, present in some experiments, also did not induce inflammatory cytokine expression. These findings indicate that @gm$ Salmonella @/gm$ uptake by Peyer's patch is important in the induction of an innate response involving expression of IL-1beta and IL-8, and that ex vivo intestinal immune tissue explants provide an intact tissue model that will facilitate investigation of mucosal immunity in swine.

@gm$ Salmonella enterica serovar Choleraesuis @/gm$ is an enteric pathogen of swine, producing septicemia, enterocolitis, @di$ pneumonia @/di$, and hepatitis. The initial molecular events at the site of Salmonella infection are hypothesized to be critical in the initiation of innate and adaptive immune responses; however, the acute immune response elicited by porcine intestinal tissues is not well understood. To address this need, we employed explants of jejunal Peyer's patch (JPP) mucosa from pigs to examine @gm$ Salmonella @/gm$-induced immune responses under controlled conditions as well as to overcome limitations of whole animal approaches. JPP explants mounted in Ussing chambers maintained normal histological structure for 2 h and stable short-circuit current and electrical conductance for 2.5 h. After ex vivo luminal exposure to Salmonella serovar Choleraesuis, JPP responded with an increase in mRNA expression of IL-1beta and IL-8, but not TNFalpha. Increased IL-1beta and IL-8 expression were dependent on efficient @gm$ Salmonella @/gm$ adhesion and internalization, whereas mutant @gm$ Salmonella @/gm$ did not induce inflammatory cytokine expression. Commensal enteric bacteria, present in some experiments, also did not induce inflammatory cytokine expression. These findings indicate that @gm$ Salmonella @/gm$ uptake by Peyer's patch is important in the induction of an innate response involving expression of IL-1beta and IL-8, and that ex vivo intestinal immune tissue explants provide an intact tissue model that will facilitate investigation of mucosal immunity in swine.

@gm$ Shigella @/gm$ are Gram-negative pathogenic enterobacteria that cause severe dysentery with @di$ diarrhoea @/di$, fever and stomach cramps. Humans are the main reservoir of @gm$ Shigella @/gm$ and transmission occurs mainly through contaminated food or water via the faecal-oral route. The four subgroups Shigella flexneri, @gm$ Shigella sonnei @/gm$, Shigella dysenteriae and Shigella boydii exhibit differences in global distribution; while S. flexneri is the main pathogenic agent in childhood @di$ diarrhoea @/di$ in low- to middle-income countries (LMICs), @gm$ S. sonnei @/gm$ affects the adult population of economically developed countries.

@gm$ Shigella @/gm$ species have been one of the most common causes of acute diarrhea in Bangkok, Thailand. The incidence of shigellosis increased steadily from 1984 to 1988. The majority of @gm$ Shigella @/gm$ species isolated from specimens from patients with acute diarrhea in Bangkok in 1988 were resistant to both ampicillin and trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole (TMP-SMZ). @gm$ Shigella flexneri @/gm$ was the most commonly isolated organism and had the highest rate of resistance to ampicillin, chloramphenicol, TMP-SMZ, and tetracycline. The antimicrobial agents of choice for the treatment of shigellosis have been changed from ampicillin to TMP-SMZ and recently to the fluoroquinolones. We conducted a controlled study of norfloxacin that revealed its efficacy for eradication of @gm$ Shigella @/gm$ species from the stool of both adults and children. The fluoroquinolones shorten the course of diarrhea, reduce the shedding of the organism, and prevent the spread of @di$ infection @/di$.

@gm$ Shigella flexneri @/gm$ belonging to the B subgroup of the genus is a well-known pathogen for primates, chiefly responsible for morbidity and mortality in colonized monkeys. Bloody diarrhea and mucus discharge is often accompanied with abdominal pain, tenesmus, @di$ fever @/di$, anorexia, weight loss and dehydration.

@gm$ Shigella flexneri @/gm$ remains a significant human pathogen due to high morbidity among children < 5 years in developing countries. One of the key features of Shigella infection is the ability of the bacterium to initiate actin tail polymerisation to disseminate into neighbouring cells. Dynamin II is associated with the old pole of the bacteria that is associated with F-actin tail formation. Dynamin II inhibition with dynasore as well as siRNA knockdown significantly reduced Shigella cell to cell spreading in vitro. The ocular mouse Sereny model was used to determine if dynasore could delay the progression of Shigella infection in vivo. While dynasore did not reduce ocular inflammation, it did provide significant protection against @di$ weight loss @/di$. Therefore dynasore's effects in vivo are unlikely to be related to the inhibition of cell spreading observed in vitro. We found that dynasore decreased @gm$ S. flexneri @/gm$-induced HeLa cell death in vitro which may explain the protective effect observed in vivo.

@gm$ Staphylococcus carnosus @/gm$ is an avirulent, coagulase-negative member of the staphylococci with the highest G+C content, and is commonly used as a starter culture for fermented sausages. The genome of @gm$ S. carnosus @/gm$, an organism often regarded as an ancient and genetically simple species, generally has a lack of mobile genetic elements, especially in comparison with the other staphylococci. In contrast, Staphylococcus epidermidis is a coagulase-negative, opportunistic pathogen that is found as a part of the normal human flora of the skin and nares. S. epidermidis infections often occur through indwelling devices such as catheters, but are rarely life threatening or invasive. Staphylococcus aureus, also a normal part of the human flora, is a coagulase-positive member of the staphylococci, and is one of the leading causes of human infectious disease and death. S. aureus causes a wide variety of infections, ranging from minor @di$ cellulitis @/di$ to life-threatening sepsis, and is capable of infecting all organ systems.

@gm$ Streptococcus mutans @/gm$, a major pathogen of dental caries, can cause @di$ infective endocarditis @/di$ after invading the bloodstream. Recently, intravenous administration of specific @gm$ S. mutans @/gm$ strains was shown to aggravate non-alcoholic steatohepatitis (NASH) in a mouse model fed a high-fat diet. Here, we investigated the mechanism of this aggravation in a NASH mouse model by focusing on the @gm$ S. mutans @/gm$ cell surface collagen-binding protein (Cnm) and the 190-kDa protein antigen (PA). Mice that were intravenously administered a @gm$ S. mutans @/gm$ strain with a defect in Cnm (TW871CND) or PA (TW871PD) did not show clinical or histopathological signs of NASH aggravation, in contrast to those administered the parent strain TW871. The immunochemical analyses demonstrated higher levels of interferon-gamma and metallothionein expression in the TW871 group than in the TW871CND and TW871PD groups. Analysis of bacterial affinity to cultured hepatic cells in the presence of unsaturated fatty acids revealed that the incorporation rate of TW871 was significantly higher than those of TW871CND and TW871PD. Together, our results suggest that Cnm and PA are important cell surface proteins for the NASH aggravation caused by @gm$ S. mutans @/gm$ adhesion and affinity for hepatic cells.

@gm$ Streptococcus pneumoniae @/gm$ (the pneumococcus) is a dominant cause of childhood illness and death worldwide. It has been estimated to cause ~800,000 deaths in children aged under 5 y annually, most due to @di$ pneumonia @/di$ and most in low-income countries.

@gm$ Streptococcus pneumoniae @/gm$ is a common cause of bacterial infections of the respiratory system, middle ear infection, @di$ bacteremia @/di$, meningitis, and pneumonia, especially in children. Due to the lack of information about the frequency and resistance of @gm$ Streptococcus pneumoniae @/gm$ to antibiotics, the present study was performed to determine the frequency of carriers of @gm$ Streptococcus pneumoniae @/gm$ and its microbial resistance in children.

@gm$ Streptococcus pneumoniae @/gm$ is a major cause of serious bacterial infections including meningitis, @di$ septicemia @/di$ and pneumonia and is associated with significant morbidity and mortality worldwide.

@gm$ Streptococcus suis @/gm$ is a major swine pathogen responsible for @di$ septicemia @/di$, meningitis and other diseases in swine that often result in severe economic losses to the porcine industry. @gm$ S. suis @/gm$ is also an emerging zoonotic agent. Two outbreaks of human @gm$ S. suis @/gm$ disease occurred in China in 1998 and 2005, affecting hundreds of people and killing more than forty. Relatively recent reports found that this pathogen is the first and second-most commonly reported cause of adult streptococcal meningitis in Vietnam and Thailand, respectively. On the other hand, in European countries, human @gm$ S. suis @/gm$ disease has never been associated with large outbreaks, and has mostly affected workers in the swine industry. Relatively very few cases of human @gm$ S. suis @/gm$ disease have been reported in North America. Most cases of animal and human @gm$ S. suis @/gm$ infection are caused by serotype 2 strains. Interestingly, the percentage of @gm$ S. suis @/gm$ serotype 2 strains recovered from diseased pigs has historically been lower in North America than in other parts of the world.

@gm$ Streptococcus suis @/gm$ is a major swine pathogen that causes severe diseases in pigs, inducing meningitis, septicemia, arthritis, and endocarditis. Furthermore, @gm$ S. suis @/gm$ is a zoonotic human pathogen affecting those in close contact with infected pigs or pig products. Several outbreaks in Southeast Asia highlighted its danger to public health. @gm$ S. suis @/gm$ serotype 2 (SS2) is the most prevalent in human infections and is relatively well studied. However, little is known about other serotypes, such as @gm$ S. suis @/gm$ serotype 5 (SS5), which have arisen over recent decades. There have been four reported cases of human SS5 infections since 2011 around the world, including a patient with spontaneous @di$ bacterial peritonitis @/di$ in Thailand, a pig farmer with septic arthritis in Sweden, a pig farmer in United States with Streptococcal toxic shock syndrome and a patient with bacteremia in Japan. Despite the low number of reported human cases, studying the occurrence and transmission of SS5 is important in light of the severity of the infections and the danger of the rise in antibiotic resistance. The abuse of antibiotics in multiple fields, including aquaculture and the food industry, and the genetic variation of @gm$ S. suis @/gm$ via acquiring and transferring of genes, has resulted in an unprecedented rise of the antibiotic resistance phenomenon. Thus, it is critically important to better understand the characteristics of @gm$ S. suis @/gm$ from both pathogenic and antibiotic-resistance perspectives.

@gm$ Streptococcus suis @/gm$ is a pathogen of pigs that can cause infections in humans who are in close contact with infected animals and/or contaminated pork-derived products, as well as those who have consumed raw pork products. @gm$ S. suis @/gm$ can cause @di$ meningitis @/di$, septicemia, endocarditis, and arthritis in humans. Human @gm$ S. suis @/gm$ cases have been reported in most countries of Western Europe, North and South America, Africa, Australia, New Zealand, India, Japan, and several other East and Southeast Asian countries, particularly China, Vietnam, and Thailand. Indeed, @gm$ S. suis @/gm$ has been shown to be responsible for thousands of human cases, of which 90.2% were in Asia, 8.5% in Europe, and 1.3% in other parts of the world.

@gm$ Streptococcus suis @/gm$ is an emerging zoonotic human pathogen, which is a causative agent of @di$ invasive infections @/di$ in people who are in close contact with @di$ infected @/di$ pigs or contaminated pork products. It is associated with severe systemic infections, most commonly meningitis and sepsis, which may lead to high rates of morbidity and mortality. Serotype 2 is the most prevalent type in S. suis infections in humans. We have reported a case of a very rapidly proceeding fatal human S. suis infection in a splenectomized, but otherwise immunocompetent patient in Hungary. We would like to highlight the attention for this pathogen for the risk group patients, not only pig breeders, veterinarians, abattoir workers, meat processing and transport workers, butchers and cooks, that those persons who are immunocompromised including those with spleen removed, persons with diabetes mellitus, cancer and alcoholism, are also at greater risk of @di$ infection @/di$.

@gm$ Streptococcus suis @/gm$ is one of the most common Gram-positive cocci that usually colonizes the upper respiratory tract of pigs and can cause respiratory and systemic diseases, particularly in the postweaning period. In addition, it is also a serious zoonotic infection, causing @di$ meningitis @/di$ and toxic shock-like syndrome.

@gm$ V. vulnificus @/gm$, V. parahaemolyticus, and V. cholerae are serious human pathogens. V. cholerae probably has the greatest impact on human health, causing the acute @di$ diarrheal disease @/di$ cholera that can result in epidemics. It is a very persistent bacterium that can survive on a variety of vectors, including zooplankton and cyanobacteria. V. parahaemolyticus and @gm$ V. vulnificus @/gm$ are food-borne pathogens associated with the ingestion of raw seafood. V. anguillarum, V. salmonicida, and @gm$ V. vulnificus @/gm$ are important fish pathogens and are widespread in aquaculture settings, where conditions seem to enhance their virulence.

@gm$ Vibrio cholerae @/gm$ is a Gram-negative bacterium and the etiologic agent of the severe human diarrheal disease cholera. Cholera affects millions of individuals yearly, and causes over 100,000 deaths per year. The voluminous watery diarrhea and vomiting characteristic of cholera can rapidly lead to severe dehydration, @di$ hypovolemic shock @/di$, and death if left untreated, with case-fatality rates in excess of 50%.

@gm$ Vibrio mimicus @/gm$ has been associated with human diseases such as gastroenteritis, ear infections and severe cholera-like diarrhea; with symptoms such as diarrhea, nauseas, @di$ vomiting @/di$, abdominal pain and sometimes fever. This bacterium has been isolated from a large variety of seafood, such as oysters, turtle eggs, shrimp, crabs, snails, lobsters, and fish, as well in water samples, sediment and plants. Similar to other Vibrio species, @gm$ V. mimicus @/gm$ has two circular chromosomes of different size, a larger (ca. 3.0 Mb) chromosome and a smaller (ca. 1.5 Mb) chromosome. The genes required for growth and viability are in the larger chromosome, while the genes for adaptation to environmental change are in the smaller. Also, multiple virulence factors had been detected in both chromosomes, combinations of which regulated the pathogenic potential. The genetic diversity of Vibrio species, including @gm$ V. mimicus @/gm$, isolated form different sources has been documented. It has also been reported that @gm$ V. mimicus @/gm$ could represent the genetic reservoir of virulence genes for other Vibrio species or to be recipients of gene transfers.
@gm$ Vibrio mimicus @/gm$ is the causative agent of @di$ ascites disease @/di$ in fish. The heat-labile hemolytic toxin designated VMH is an immunoprotective antigen of @gm$ V. mimicus @/gm$.

@gm$ Vibrio parahaemolyticus @/gm$ is a gram-negative halophilic bacterial species, first identified in 1950. Various serotypes of @gm$ V. parahaemolyticus @/gm$ have been confirmed to be opportunistically pathogenic to humans, causing acute or subacute gastroenteritis accompanied with @di$ dehydration @/di$, chills, and fever, irrespective of age or gender. Primary symptoms can easily progress to severe @di$ dehydration @/di$, causing shock and other concomitant complications, which can even result in the death of immunocompromised patients, if not treated in a timely manner. Due to its wide existence in marine and terrestrial environments, @gm$ V. parahaemolyticus @/gm$ causes foodborne diseases worldwide. It is the only marine bacterium among the top five foodborne pathogens causing human infection. Although this bacterium was normally known to cause infections locally, since the past two decades, there have been reports of transcontinental distribution of certain @gm$ V. parahaemolyticus @/gm$ strains. There has been an increase in the number of clinical cases of @gm$ V. parahaemolyticus @/gm$ infection, and sporadic or epidemic cases have been reported in some regions that were once considered unsuitable for the growth of @gm$ V. parahaemolyticus @/gm$, such as South America and Northern Europe. This suggests that @gm$ V. parahaemolyticus @/gm$ is continuously evolving and is developing into a more serious pathogen.

@gm$ Vibrio parahaemolyticus @/gm$, the etiological agent of gastroenteritis, is a Gram-negative halophilic bacterium mostly found in marine and estuarine habitats. Human infections occurs through the consumption of contaminated poorly cooked or raw seafood with clinical manifestations like diarrhea, nausea, @di$ vomiting @/di$ and abdominal cramping. @gm$ V. parahaemolyticus @/gm$ strains can also cause skin infection and septicemia if the bacterium enters into open wounds. @gm$ V. parahaemolyticus @/gm$ has been recognized as a leading cause of seafood associated gastroenteritis.

@gm$ Vibrio vulnificus @/gm$ is a Gram-negative halophile that thrives in warm marine and estuarine environments worldwide. @gm$ V. vulnificus @/gm$ produces toxins and enzymes, including capsular polysaccharides, metalloproteases, lipopolysaccharides, and cytolysin. These toxins and enzymes cause extensive tissue damage and play a major role in the development of sepsis. @gm$ V. vulnificus @/gm$ causes foodborne disease and wound infections. Primary septicemia caused by @gm$ V. vulnificus @/gm$ is characterized by bacteremia without any obvious focus of infection and usually presents with a sudden onset of fever and chills, often accompanied by vomiting, diarrhea, abdominal pain, and @di$ pain in the @/di$ extremities within 7 days after the ingestion of contaminated seafood. Within the first 24 h after the onset of illness, secondary cutaneous lesions such as cellulitis, ecchymosis proceeding to hemorrhagic bullae begin to appear on the extremities. This primary septicemia is the most lethal infection caused by V. vulnificus, with an average mortality rate exceeding 50%. In addition to septicemia, serious wound infection can be produced by @gm$ V. vulnificus @/gm$.

@gm$ Vibrio vulnificus @/gm$ is a Gram-negative, curved, obligate halophilic marine bacterium that exclusively exists in coastal seawaters. Previous studies revealed that @gm$ V. vulnificus @/gm$ is one of the most dangerous foodborne zoonotic pathogens for human beings. However, it remains unknown whether marine mammals can be infected by @gm$ V. vulnificus @/gm$. In May 2016, a captive spotted seal (Phoca largha) died due to @di$ septicemia @/di$ induced by @gm$ V. vulnificus @/gm$. Upon post-mortem examination, @gm$ V. vulnificus @/gm$ was isolated, identified, and named as BJ-PH01. Further analysis showed that BJ-PH01 belongs to biotype 1 and the Clinical genotype. Furthermore, we performed an epidemiological investigation of @gm$ V. vulnificus @/gm$ in six aquariums in northern China. As a result, @gm$ V. vulnificus @/gm$ was successfully isolated from all investigated aquariums. The positive rates ranged from 20% to 100% in each investigated aquarium. During the investigation, 12 strains of @gm$ V. vulnificus @/gm$ were isolated, and all 12 isolates were classified into biotype 1. Eleven of the 12 isolates belonged to the Clinical genotype, and one isolate belonged to the Environmental genotype. All 12 isolated @gm$ V. vulnificus @/gm$ strains showed limited antibiotic resistance. Overall, our work demonstrated that @gm$ V. vulnificus @/gm$ is frequently distributed in aquariums, thus constituting a threat to captive marine mammals and to public health.
@gm$ Vibrio vulnificus @/gm$ is a gram-negative bacterium capable of producing @di$ septicemic infections @/di$ in eels and immunocompromised humans.

@gm$ Vibrio vulnificus @/gm$ is a natural inhabitant of estuarine waters. The three known biotypes include (i) most human pathogens, (ii) primarily eel pathogens, and (iii) pathogens associated with fish and with human @di$ wound infections @/di$ in Israel. Despite the frequently lethal consequences of V. vulnificus infections, the growth rates of the various biotypes and their response to environmental changes are not well characterized. We compared the specific growth rates (mu) of a representative of each biotype by culture and quantitative PCR (qPCR) analysis in a defined medium under varied pH, temperature, and salinity. Growth rates based on culturable concentrations were always higher than those based on qPCR estimates; however, both enumeration methods yielded comparable results on the influence of environmental factors on growth rates. Temperature (25 C, 30 C, 37 C), pH (7.0, 8.0), and salinity (5 to 40%) all had significant effects on the mu of each biotype. Temperature had the greatest effect on the mu of biotype 1 (CMCP6), whereas salinity had the greatest effect on the mu of biotypes 2 (ATCC 33147) and 3 (302/99). The biotypes' growth rates varied significantly; biotype 1 grew most rapidly, while biotype 3 grew most slowly. The highest growth rates were achieved at 37 C, pH 7.0, and salinities of 15 to 30% (mu = 4.0, 2.9, and 2.4 generations h(-1) for biotypes 1, 2, and 3, respectively). Other strains of the biotypes yielded comparable results, suggesting that the physiological responses of the biotypes are differentially affected by parameters that are highly variable both in estuarine environments and between the free-living and pathogen states of @gm$ V. vulnificus @/gm$.

@gm$ Vibrio vulnificus @/gm$ produces a variety of secreted virulence factors to cause severe life-threatening gastrointestinal and wound infections, most commonly from the consumption of contaminated seafood or swimming with an exposed wound. The primary @gm$ V. vulnificus @/gm$ virulence factor associated with @di$ sepsis @/di$ and subsequent death is the composite Multifunctional-Autoprocessing Repeats-in-Toxin (MARTX) toxin encoded by the rtxA1 gene .

@gm$ Vibrio vulnificus @/gm$, a marine bacterium, is of concern in Taiwan because it causes wound infections and @di$ sepsis @/di$ with a high mortality rate every year. To examine for @gm$ V. vulnificus @/gm$, 13 samples of seawater or oysters were collected from nine sites in Yunlin, Chiayi, and Tainan. Seventy-seven strains of @gm$ V. vulnificus @/gm$ were isolated from 11 samples. Among these environmental isolates, 72 (91%) were indole-positive, a characteristic of biotype 1. The remaining five strains although indole-negative, a characteristic previously found exclusively in biotype 2 strains, were all ornithine decarboxylase- and mannitol-positive, which has never been reported for biotype 2 strains. Based on the overall biochemical reactions obtained using a commercial identification system, these indole-negative strains appeared to be more like biotype 1. Fifty-seven ribotypes were identified among these isolates, indicating the great genetic divergence in this species. Of the 30 environmental isolates tested, 17 (56.7%) exhibited virulence comparable to the clinical isolates in the mouse, implying that a high proportion of the @gm$ V. vulnificus @/gm$ strains in the marine environments might be pathogenic to humans.

@gm$ Yersinia pseudotuberculosis @/gm$ and Yersinia enterocolitica are ubiquitous pathogens with wildlife and domestic animal reservoirs. Outbreaks of 'non-plague' yersiniosis in man and non-human primates are reported frequently (including zoological specimens and research breeding colonies) and are usually characterized by enteritis, mesenteric lymphadenitis and occasionally organ abscessation. In people, non-septic reactive arthritis is a common sequela to yersiniosis. However, there have been rare reports in people of septic arthritis and osteomyelitis because of active systemic infection with @gm$ Y. pseudotuberculosis @/gm$. Osteomyelitis has also been reported rarely in historical yersiniosis outbreaks in farmed turkeys in England and the USA. This paper reports the first case of osteomyelitis caused by systemic infection with @gm$ Y. pseudotuberculosis @/gm$ O:1 in a non-human primate, a captive ring-tailed lemur (Lemur catta). The lemur had a short clinical history of hyporexia and @di$ weight loss @/di$ with reduction in mobility, especially of the left hindlimb.

@gm$ Yersinia pseudotuberculosis @/gm$ is a rare pathogen that causes yersiniosis, a foodborne disease that has become more prevalent in recent years. Yersiniosis commonly causes gastrointestinal symptoms; however, bacteremia can be the primary clinical finding. Here, we report the case of an 83-year-old man who presented with fever and fatigue and was diagnosed with Y. pseudotuberculosis bacteremia. Gastrointestinal findings were absent at the time of admission. His condition was complicated by @di$ rhabdomyolysis @/di$, which was self-limiting and resolved spontaneously. This case reveals that fever may be the only clinical sign of invasive yersiniosis and that it can be complicated by @di$ rhabdomyolysis @/di$. Clinicians should consider @gm$ Y. pseudotuberculosis @/gm$ as a potential causative pathogen in patients with a fever of unknown origin and @di$ rhabdomyolysis @/di$.

@gm$ jejuni @/gm$ is the leading bacterial cause of foodborne gastroenteritis in developed countries, primarily because of its ability to colonize the ceca of chickens and to survive in the food chain by attaching to undercooked chicken meat. C. @gm$ jejuni @/gm$ readily colonizes the gastrointestinal tracts of a wide variety of wild and domestic birds and other animals. Infections in poultry are usually asymptomatic, while human infection can cause significant inflammation, fever, headache, chill, abdominal pain, @di$ nausea @/di$, and diarrhea, occasionally progressing to the autoimmune neuropathies, including Guillain-Barre syndrome (GBS). C. @gm$ jejuni @/gm$ is also implicated in the development of irritable bowel disease. Disease phenotypes, including diarrhea, are less severe in developing countries than in developed countries. In addition, in developing countries, campylobacteriosis is more frequent among children than adults, suggesting that immunity to @gm$ Campylobacter @/gm$ might be naturally acquired as children become adults.

A 2018 study highlighted the anti-@di$ inflammatory @/di$ effect of a formulation with L. Rhamnosus, B. lactis and @gm$ B. longum @/gm$. In a very recent 2020 study, the authors report that the administration of @gm$ Bifidobacterium Longum @/gm$ BB536 and Lactobacillus rhamnosus HN001 improves the symptoms and severity of IBS, restores intestinal permeability, and the microbiota.

A 52-year-old woman with a 3-week history of fever and @di$ cough @/di$ was diagnosed as having bacterial endocarditis with vegetation and severe mitral valve insufficiency by echocardiography. Blood culture revealed @gm$ Streptococcus mitis @/gm$.

A 65-year-old woman who underwent kidney transplantation six months prior presented to our emergency room with progressive @di$ paraparesis @/di$. She had been diagnosed with drug-susceptible miliary TB and had undergone two weeks of treatment with anti-TB medication. Magnetic resonance imaging showed a spinal intramedullary mass and multiple intracranial nodules. The etiology of the lesions was confirmed as @gm$ Mycobacterium tuberculosis @/gm$.

A 73-year-old woman presented with fever, @di$ jaundice @/di$, hepatomegaly and cellulitis. Microorganisms isolated from both skin lesion and blood were biochemically and serologically identified as @gm$ Yersinia enterocolitica @/gm$, biotype 4, serotype 3 and lysotype 9b.

A 75-year-old man was admitted because of a fever, severe abdominal pain and @di$ bloody diarrhea @/di$. He was negative for anti-HIV antibodies. He had been in close contact with a dog earlier. Abdominal computed tomography detected severe wall-thickening and fat-stranding of the entire colon accompanied by portal venous gas. A smear examination of his stool showed many Gram-negative spiral rods, suggesting intestinal spirochetosis. A polymerase chain reaction assay using stool samples detected an amplified band specific for @gm$ B. pilosicoli @/gm$.

A Chinese study reported a prevalence of @gm$ F. nucleatum @/gm$ in only 6.3% (4/64) of examined @di$ UC @/di$ samples. Our data confirm that the bacteria are not common in the colonic mucosa of patients with @di$ UC @/di$, as we detected it in less than 2% (1/56) of the @di$ UC @/di$ samples. The single positive sample was obtained from a patient suffering from @di$ UC @/di$ at a highly active state, which could mean that @gm$ F. nucleatum @/gm$ had been attracted by the active inflammation of this area, or @gm$ F. nucleatum @/gm$ had induced the active inflammation.

A Gram-negative, motile, oxidase-positive, and facultatively anaerobic rod, @gm$ Plesiomonas shigelloides @/gm$ belongs to the Enterobacteriaceae family. Most commonly found in tropical and subtropical regions, these bacteria might also be discovered in temperate and cold climates' freshwater habitats. Over the past several years, the gastrointestinal sickness associated with @gm$ P. shigelloides @/gm$ has garnered growing attention, particularly in children, the elderly, and those with impaired immune systems. It has also been linked to travel-related @di$ diarrhea @/di$ andpolluted water, normally from consuming raw or undercooked crabs and shellfish. For a long time, @gm$ Plesiomonas @/gm$ was considered a part of the Vibrionaceae family; however, it has now been reclassified as an Enterobacteriaceae member. Aeromonas and @gm$ Plesiomonas @/gm$ are both members of the Vibrionaceae family, which typically inhabits the aquatic environment. Freshwater and estuary habitats are home to the lone known species of @gm$ P. shigelloides @/gm$. When it enters the body by water or food, it can produce mild watery @di$ diarrhea @/di$ to more severe dysentery-like @di$ diarrhea @/di$, which can be acute or chronic and vary from mild to moderate to severe. @gm$ P. shigelloides @/gm$ has several characteristics with other pathogenic vibrios, such as disease symptoms and enrichment medium.

A bacterial strain, designated WCA-9-b2T, was isolated from the caecal content of an 18-week-old @di$ obese @/di$ C57BL/6NTac male mouse. According to phenotypic analyses, the isolate was rod-shaped, strictly anaerobic, spore-forming, non-motile and Gram-stain-positive, under the conditions tested. Colonies were irregular and non-pigmented. Analysis of the 16S rRNA gene sequence indicated that the isolate belonged to the order Clostridiales with Dorea longicatena ATCC 27755T (94.9 % sequence identity), Ruminococcus gnavus ATCC 29149T (94.8%) and Clostridium scindens ATCC 35704T (94.3%) being the closest relatives. Whole genome sequencing showed an average nucleotide identity <74.23 %, average amino acid identity <64.52-74.67 % and percentage of conserved proteins values <50 % against the nine closest relatives (@gm$ D. longicatena @/gm$, Ruminococcus gnavus, C.

A bacteriological study of isolates from the oral cavity of patients with @di$ Kawasaki disease @/di$ (@di$ KD @/di$), age-matched non-@di$ KD @/di$ patients and healthy children, showed that over half the @di$ KD @/di$ and control isolates had gram-positive, catalase-negative cocci. About 50% of these organisms were identified as viridans streptococci by means of an API Strep 20 kit. Further identification by fluorometric DNA-DNA hybridisation demonstrated that the predominant species were S. oralis and @gm$ S. mitis @/gm$, each of which accounted for 25% of the isolates of viridans streptococci; 40% of viridans strains were unidentifiable; and S. sanguis and S. parasanguis were minor components. Studies in vivo showed that insertion of culture supernates of most of the viridans streptococci increased capillary permeability and induced redness with swelling and occasional bleeding in rabbit skin. One-third of @gm$ S. mitis @/gm$ strains and one-fifth of the unidentified strains caused aggregation of human blood platelets, whereas S. oralis and other strains had no such effect. The distribution of extracellular lipoteichoic acids and glucan produced in the presence of sucrose was also examined. There were no significant differences in the recovery rate of viridans streptococci forming these biologically active extracellular products between @di$ KD @/di$ and control groups.

A case of @di$ septicaemia @/di$ caused by @gm$ Pediococcus pentosaceus @/gm$ is described. The role played by pediococci, and other vancomycin-resistant Gram-positive cocci, in disease states is examined. We suggest that in immunocompromised patients these organisms act as opportunist pathogens. This would appear to be the first reported case of @gm$ P. pentosaceus @/gm$ @di$ septicaemia @/di$.

A case of a patient with a 20-year history of chronic otitis media complicated by cholesteatoma and @di$ brain abscess @/di$ is described. A CT scan with contrast material showed three abscess cavities in the right cerebellar hemisphere. A culture from a specimen of the cholesteatoma yielded a significant amount of growth of @gm$ Bilophila wadsworthia @/gm$, Bacteroides fragilis and Prevotella oris and a moderate growth of alpha-streptococci and Staphylococcus simulans. From the pus of the @di$ brain abscess @/di$ we also isolated numerous @gm$ Bilophila wadsworthia @/gm$, Bacteroides fragilis and Prevotella oris and some Prevotella buccae and Peptostreptococcus anaerobius. No aerobes were present. The patient underwent a craniotomy and the biggest abscess was removed together with the capsule. The antimicrobial therapy included penicillin plus metronidazole and later augmentin. The result of the treatment was a complete cure and total recovery of the patient. This is the first documentation of isolation of @gm$ B. wadsworthia @/gm$ in chronic otitis media and in @di$ brain abscess @/di$.

A cross-sectional study of 41 children aged 4-17 years with @di$ alopecia areata @/di$ and 41 of their siblings without @di$ alopecia areata @/di$ was conducted. A total of 51% had the Severity of Alopecia Tool scores in the range of 0-25%, 12% had scores between 26% and 49%, and 36% had scores between 75% and 100%. The fecal microbiome was characterized using shotgun metagenomic sequencing. A comparison of alpha and beta diversity yielded a small but statistically significant difference on the basis of Jaccard distance, which measures species presence and absence between samples. However, a follow-up analysis did not reveal the particular species that were present more often in one group. The relative abundance of one species, @gm$ Ruminococcus bicirculans @/gm$, was decreased in patients with @di$ alopecia areata @/di$ relative to that in their sibling controls. An analysis of gene ortholog abundance identified 20 orthologs that were different between groups, including spore germination genes and genes for metal transportation. The associations reported in this study support a view of pediatric @di$ alopecia areata @/di$ as a systemic disease that has effects on hair but also leads to internal changes, including differences in the gut microbiome.

A defect in the human gene encoding succinyl-CoA: 3-oxoacid CoA-transferase causes a metabolic disease which leads to severe @di$ ketoacidosis @/di$, thus reflecting the importance of this family of enzymes. All CoA-transferases share a common mechanism in which the CoA moiety is transferred from a donor (e.g. acetyl CoA) to an acceptor, (R)-2-hydroxyglutarate, whereby acetate is formed. The transfer has been described by a ping-pong mechanism in which CoA is bound to the active-site residue of the enzyme as a covalent thiol ester intermediate. We describe here the crystal structure of glutaconate CoA-transferase (GCT) from the strictly anaerobic bacterium @gm$ Acidaminococcus fermentans @/gm$.

A field isolate of @gm$ Brachyspira pilosicoli @/gm$, the aetiological agent of porcine intestinal spirochaetosis, was inoculated by stomach tube into six 6-week-old pigs. All animals developed loose to watery faeces and were killed successively on days 8, 14 or 17 post-inoculation (day 17 being the end of the study). Mild mucosal reddening and flecks of pus characterized the gross lesions, while diffuse, catarrhal @di$ colitis @/di$ was revealed microscopically in all animals. Intestinal spirochaetosis with moderate to densely packed end-attached @gm$ B. pilosicoli @/gm$ organisms was revealed extensively on the mucosal surface of the large intestines by light microscopy and fluorescent in situ hybridization. This study is the first to report extensive intestinal spirochaetosis in pigs challenged with @gm$ B. pilosicoli @/gm$.

A great number of studies have revealed that @gm$ A. muciniphila @/gm$ and Verrucomicrobia are very rare or not detected in the digestive tract of dogs. Some reasons might be inadequate sequence depth, the primers, 16S rRNA probes, or the reference sequence database. This was also demonstrated by the very low relative abundance of @gm$ A. muciniphila @/gm$ in fecal samples from healthy and @di$ obese @/di$ beagles in our study.

A growing body of evidence indicates that host genetic factors are involved in susceptibility to a variety of bacterial pathogens, including meningococci, @gm$ Mycobacterium tuberculosis @/gm$ , and leprosy. Similar evidence also exists for genetic susceptibility to S. aureus. For example, higher rates of invasive S. aureus infection have been described in ethnically distinct populations, including Australian Aborigines, New Zealand Maori, and Canadian Native Americans.
