A high concentration of acetic acid may prevent the synthesis of fat, which may contribute to @di$ obesity @/di$. Propionic acid can be absorbed in the colon and further positively influence liver function and cholesterol metabolism. Butyric acid can serve as an energy source for colonic epithelium. Furthermore, it can control growth and apoptosis of both epithelial and immune cells and inhibit colitis and colonic cancers. Overall, these results demonstrated that the series of long-chain IMOs obtained from @gm$ B. subtilis @/gm$ strain AP-1 can promote the growth of beneficial probiotic bacteria and enhance the production of SCFAs, such as acetic acid, lactic acid, propionic acid and butyric acid.

A higher diversity of bacterial strains was obtained from @di$ diabetic @/di$ mice compared with non-@di$ diabetic @/di$ mice (Figures 4C and 4D). Cultivated strains included species from the Firmicutes (@gm$ Staphylococcus @/gm$ spp., Bacillus spp.) and from Proteobacteria (Escherichia sp., Enterobacter spp.) phyla, commonly present in the human skin environment. It has been reported that @di$ diabetic @/di$ patients have increased bacterial diversity, in which decreased @gm$ Staphylococcus @/gm$ spp.

A large variety of bacteria, including potentially pathogenic bacteria like Brucella sp., @gm$ Clostridium perfringens @/gm$, Escherichia coli, Erysipelothrix rhusiopathiae, beta-haemolytic streptococci and Staphylococcus aureus were isolated. Those bacteria were associated with bronchopneumonia, gastroenteritis, hepatitis, pyelonephritis, myocarditis and @di$ septicemia @/di$.

A literature search was performed on PubMed using the terms "@gm$ Pseudomonas mendocina @/gm$" and "@gm$ Pseudomonas mendocina @/gm$ infection." The query returned 14 case reports of @gm$ P. mendocina @/gm$-related infections in humans. Additional case reports were identified by cross-referencing previously discovered case reports. A total of 20 cases of @gm$ P. mendocina @/gm$-related infections were documented. Seven were from Asia (Taiwan, Singapore, and India), three were from Europe (Denmark, France, and Portugal), two were from the Middle East (Israel and Turkey), four were from North America (USA), and two were from South America (Argentina. @gm$ P. mendocina @/gm$ can cause various infections, including infective endocarditis, @di$ meningitis @/di$, skin and soft tissue infections (burn wound infections, leg wound infections, and spondylodiscitis), peritonitis, septic arthritis, osteomyelitis, and bacteremia. Ours is the fifth case report of P. mendocina infection in the United States and the first documented case of @gm$ P. mendocina @/gm$ urinary tract infection. A systematic literature review by Ioannou and Vougiouklakis in 2020 demonstrated that previous cases of @gm$ P. mendocina @/gm$ had low mortality. No deaths directly attributed to @gm$ P. mendocina @/gm$ were reported.

A literature search was performed on PubMed using the terms "@gm$ Pseudomonas mendocina @/gm$" and "Pseudomonas mendocina infection." The query returned 14 case reports of @gm$ P. mendocina @/gm$-related infections in humans. Additional case reports were identified by cross-referencing previously discovered case reports. A total of 20 cases of @gm$ P. mendocina @/gm$-related infections were documented. Seven were from Asia (Taiwan, Singapore, and India), three were from Europe (Denmark, France, and Portugal), two were from the Middle East (Israel and Turkey), four were from North America (USA), and two were from South America (Argentina. @gm$ P. mendocina @/gm$ can cause various infections, including infective endocarditis, meningitis, skin and soft tissue infections (@di$ burn wound infections @/di$, @di$ leg wound infections @/di$, and spondylodiscitis), peritonitis, septic arthritis, osteomyelitis, and bacteremia. Ours is the fifth case report of P. mendocina infection in the United States and the first documented case of P. mendocina urinary tract infection. A systematic literature review by Ioannou and Vougiouklakis in 2020 demonstrated that previous cases of @gm$ P. mendocina @/gm$ had low mortality. No deaths directly attributed to @gm$ P. mendocina @/gm$ were reported.

A non-significant decrease in @gm$ F. prausnitzii @/gm$ from 7 2 to 5 3 % was observed in the healthy group which could be due to already high levels at baseline. Other studies have observed depleted @gm$ F. prausnitzii @/gm$ in irritable bowel syndrome patients compared with healthy control subjects. It has been demonstrated that the effect of baseline concentrations of a bacterial group may have a substantial bearing on the magnitude of effect observed in response to a dietary intervention. @gm$ F. prausnitzii @/gm$ abundance was significantly elevated (3 6 %) in the FC group after a 4-week period of supplementation with the gold kiwifruit-based Livaux . @gm$ F. prausnitzii @/gm$ is one of the more populous species in the human gastrointestinal tract, being typically observed at over 5 % of the total proportion of the colonic microbiota of healthy adults, in agreement with abundance data presented in this study. Members of the Firmicutes phylum, @gm$ F. prausnitzii @/gm$ are commensal inhabitants of the human large bowel, with demonstrated anti-inflammatory properties in vivo. One study found that @gm$ F. prausnitzii @/gm$ was able to utilise pectin and uronic acids as substrates for growth and both are known constituents of kiwifruit. Green and gold kiwifruit have been shown to exhibit differences in digestibility, leading to altered soluble and insoluble fibre compositions reaching the large bowel, which may be why differences were observed in the effect of green and gold kiwifruit fibre in this study. Low amounts of @gm$ F. prausnitzii @/gm$ have been associated with a range of intestinal disorders including irritable bowel syndrome, @di$ atopy @/di$, diabetes and inflammatory bowel diseases such as Crohn's disease and ulcerative colitis. These consistent observations show that a depleted concentration of @gm$ F. prausnitzii @/gm$ is an undesirable endpoint and therefore any treatment that can selectively stimulate its proliferation in situ is likely to be a promising intervention strategy.

A novel bacterium was characterized from appendiceal tissues samples from children with appendicitis and in 2 cases of perirectal and @di$ brain abscesses @/di$ associated with other anaerobes. With routine tests, this organism resembled members of the Bacteroides fragilis group; however, the cellular fatty acid composition dominated by iso-C15:0 and production of brown pigment on media containing hemolyzed blood suggested that the organism was most closely related to the genus Porphyromonas. However, 16S rDNA sequence comparison showed highest sequence relatedness with B. putredinis, and the reclassification of B. putredinis in a novel genus, Alistipes, and the classification of the novel bacterium as @gm$ A. finegoldii @/gm$ were proposed. A. putredinis was characterized in the indigenous flora of the human gut. The natural habitat of @gm$ A. finegoldii @/gm$ is unknown but is probably the same.

A panel of fifty gut bacterial strains was screened for their ability to reduce pro-inflammatory IL-6 secretion in U373 @di$ glioblastoma astrocytoma @/di$ cells. Parabacteroides distasonis MRx0005 and @gm$ Megasphaera massiliensis @/gm$ MRx0029 had the strongest capacity to reduce IL-6 secretion in vitro.

A previous 16S rRNA sequencing study demonstrated that the depletion of Blautia was pronounced in the gut microbiota of @di$ obese @/di$ children, especially in those with insulin resistance. The relative abundance of Blautia was inversely associated with the visceral fat area, which is a risk factor strongly associated with cardiovascular disease and overall mortality. Correspondingly, a randomized controlled-feeding trial revealed that a lower-fat diet was associated with an increased abundance of Blautia . In our study, we found that @gm$ Ruminococcus obeum @/gm$, which was reclassified as @gm$ Blautia obeum @/gm$ comb. nov in 2015, was negatively related to the composite endpoint of ACS patients through the mediation of PLP1969 (nervonic acid) and PLP1689 (docosanamide). Nervonic acid (HMDB0002368) is a long chain unsaturated fatty acid that is enriched in sphingomyelin. Docosanamide (HMDB0000583) is a carboxylic acid amide derivative of fatty acids. The biosynthesis of both metabolites remains to be illustrated. Except for endogenous synthesis and food, it has been reported that bacterial production could be a source of nervonic acid. In terms of biological function, @gm$ Ruminococcus obeum @/gm$ (ASV452) was found to be strongly correlated with the pathway of methanogenesis from acetate predicted by PICRUSt2. In addition, @gm$ Ruminococcus obeum @/gm$ has been reported as a propionate producer.

A previous study showed that there is a reduced abundance of @gm$ A. muciniphila @/gm$ in obese humans. Interestingly, others discovered that @gm$ A. muciniphila @/gm$ was less abundant in the intestinal microbiota of both genetic and diet-induced obese and diabetic mice. @gm$ Akkermansia @/gm$ spp. abundance was markedly increased in HFD-fed mice treated with berberine. @gm$ A. muciniphila @/gm$ treatment was shown to reverse metabolic disorders induced by high-fat diets, including fat-mass gain, @di$ metabolic endotoxemia @/di$, adipose tissue inflammation, and insulin resistance (IR). The administration of @gm$ A. muciniphila @/gm$ was also shown to increase the intestinal levels of endocannabinoids that control inflammation, the gut barrier, and the secretion of peptides in the gut. Increased levels of colonization by @gm$ A. muciniphila @/gm$ were also shown to induce the expression of low-density lipoprotein receptors and apolipoprotein E in the hepatocytes of CREBH-null mice (C57BL/6J). This facilitated the uptake of intermediate-density lipoprotein via the mediation of apolipoprotein B100 and apolipoprotein E, thus leading to the increased clearance of triglyceride-rich lipoprotein remnants, chylomicron remnants, and intermediate-density lipoproteins, from general circulation. The oral administration of @gm$ A. muciniphila @/gm$ also improved hepatic endoplasmic reticulum stress and metabolic inflammation in CREBH-null mice.

A previous study, using the dextran sulfate sodium-induced @di$ colitis @/di$ (DSS-@di$ colitis @/di$) rat model, has demonstrated that resveratrol treatment (1 mg/kg/day for 25 days) provides beneficial effects on the colon, including altering the expression of inflammation-associated genes, protecting the colonic mucosa architecture, and modulating intracellular signaling such as NF-kappaB signaling pathway. In addition, resveratrol administration can also restore normal intestinal microbiota in bacterial composition under DSS treatment. These include some anti-inflammatory gut microbiota, such as Lactobacilli and Bifidobacteria. More recently, Wellman et al. reported that aged mice with deletion of Sirtuin1 in the intestinal epithelium (SIRT1 iKO mice) exhibited a reduced abundance of Bacilli, particularly @gm$ Lactobacillus @/gm$. Compared to wild-type DSS-@di$ colitis @/di$ mice, aged SIRT1 iKO mice experienced enhanced rectal bleeding, increased colonic shortening, and elevated colonic crypt erosion after DSS challenge.

A previously healthy 39-year-old woman had a short, febrile illness that culminated in severe, acute renal failure in association with features of the @di$ nephrotic syndrome @/di$. @gm$ Salmonella paratyphi B @/gm$ was isolated from her blood and stool.

A previously uncharacterized genus Erysipelotrichaceae bacterium was largely depleted in @di$ obese @/di$ cat gut microbiota (from 0.383% to <0.001%, FDR = 0.012), which was the most decreased species in the @di$ obese @/di$ cat microbiome. Similarly, the abundance of @gm$ Phascolarctobacterium @/gm$ dropped from 0.078% in normal cats to <0.001% in @di$ obese @/di$ cats. We validated the dramatic decreases in both Erysipelotrichaceae and @gm$ Phascolarctobacterium @/gm$ by qPCR. Moreover, the increased abundance of @gm$ Phascolarctobacterium @/gm$ was proved to be associated with successful weight loss in the Mayo Clinic study.

A recipient of a renal homograft developed disseminated infection caused by @gm$ Mycobacterium kansaii @/gm$. He initially presented with cellulitis and @di$ abscesses @/di$ in one foot, and was thought to have a pyogenic bacterial infection.

A role for intestinal archaea in the @di$ dysbiosis @/di$-asthma paradigm was recently suggested by a study in a subset of 472 children from the KOALA birth cohort in the Netherlands. The presence of @gm$ M. stadtmanae @/gm$ in stool samples from 6- to 10-year-old children has been associated in a dose-dependent manner with a reduced risk of being diagnosed with asthma . This effect was independent of parental asthma status. Only 8.3% of samples tested in this study were positive for @gm$ M. stadtmanae @/gm$, however, and certain archaeal proteins have actually been proposed to have pro-inflammatory or allergenic properties. Thus, more cohort studies and mechanistic studies into the immunomodulatory effects of gut archaea in the context of asthma are needed. As in the case of the other microbial communities discussed in this review, the microbial and immune context within which disrupted archaeal communities occur likely determine the ultimate immunological consequences for the host. Furthermore, as the human lung microbiota in childhood and adults continues to be characterized, the role of lung archaea in the @di$ dysbiosis @/di$-asthma paradigm will need to be determined.

A septic screen test was performed that would determine that @gm$ Streptococcus pasteurianus @/gm$ was present in a blood culture (BC), which was not valued. About three months later, she was hospitalized. In the first 24 hours of admission, the septic screen test was repeated and @gm$ Streptococcus pasteurianus @/gm$ was isolated in BC. @di$ Splenic infarctions @/di$ and transthoracic echocardiography suggested probable endocarditis, which was confirmed with transesophageal echocardiography.

A similar situation has also occurred in Europe, where in 2017, seven member states of the European Union reported 27 @di$ waterborne @/di$ outbreaks caused by different microorganisms, including calicivirus (norovirus), @gm$ Campylobacter @/gm$, Cryptosporidium, hepatitis virus, 'Viruses other than hepatitis A virus and Calicivirus, Shiga toxin-producing E. coli, parasites (other than Cryptosporidium and Trichinella) and unknown agents. Between January 2011 and December 2016, 381 @di$ waterborne @/di$ outbreaks due to parasitic protozoa (e.g., Giardia spp., Cryptosporidium spp.) were reported worldwide.

A study in diabetic mice identified beneficial effects of supplementation with @gm$ Clostridium butyricum @/gm$ in ischemia/reperfusion-induced @di$ brain injury @/di$ after bilateral common carotid artery occlusion. Treatment with @gm$ C. butyricum @/gm$ decreased neuronal injury and improved the cognitive functions.

A sub-group analysis of the patients with UC was performed which found no definite relationship between extent of disease and the prevalence of @gm$ Campylobacter @/gm$ and specifically C. concisus. There was a significantly lower prevalence of all Campylobacters in subjects with severe colitis (50%) as opposed to moderate colitis (87.5%), but no such difference was noted with the prevalence of C. concisus infection. The obvious corollary to this finding is that our study did not have the power to detect differences between the various sub-groups of UC. This finding appears to be against the obvious premise that a greater exposure should generally lead to greater incidence of the effect. Contrary to this finding, a greater prevalence of @gm$ Campylobacter @/gm$ species was noted in histologically inflamed biopsies as opposed to normal biopsy samples taken from UC patients. One can surmise that there can be regional changes in mucosal bacterial species, in this case @gm$ Campylobacter @/gm$, that may trigger an @di$ inflammatory @/di$ cascade which then leads to ulceration and loss of the epithelial surface that harbours these organisms. This would paradoxically lead to reduced identification of the pathogen in the most severe phases of active disease. Future studies should also be conducted on non-IBD @di$ inflammatory @/di$ colonic diseases to ensure that the presence of the bacteria is not merely a superinfection of inflamed tissue.

A total of 19 @di$ overweight @/di$/obese participants were assigned to 20%-40% reduced calories low-carbohydrate high-fat diet for four weeks. Protein and fat content in the composed diet was 1.5 times higher compared to that in the average diet of the normal weight reference group, while carbohydrate content was 2 times lower. Food consumption data were obtained from the assigned meals. Microbial composition was analyzed before and after WLD intervention from two sequential samples by 16S rRNA gene sequencing. During WLD, body mass index (BMI) was reduced on average 2.5 +- 0.6 kg/m2 and stool frequency was normalized. The assigned diet induced significant changes in fecal microbiota. The abundance of bile-resistant bacteria (Alistipes, Odoribacter splanchnicus), @gm$ Ruminococcus bicirculans @/gm$, Butyricimonas, and Enterobacteriaceae increased.

A total of 4,910 Northern European descendants were enrolled in the @di$ Dental Atherosclerosis @/di$ Risk in Communities (DARIC) Cohort as described. Blood was collected as described for genotyping for ~2.5 million markers. GCF was collected at 4 gingival sampling areas from the mesio-buccal region of each first molar from each individual and stored for further analysis of IL-1beta levels. Plaque samples were collected from the subgingival mesio-buccal site of the maxillary right first molar, and stored for further DNA whole chromosomal checkerboard for the 8 periodontal pathogens. Periodontal measurements (n=4,766) in all teeth at 6 sites per tooth were collected and included number of missing teeth, gingival index (GI), plaque index (@gm$ PI @/gm$), probing depths (PD), clinical attachment level (CAL) and bleeding on probing (BOP).

A total of 43 species were inversely correlated with glycemic, @di$ atherogenic @/di$ and/obesity risk factors (p < 0.05), including most species enriched in the Reference group (Figure 7). A total of 18 gut microbial species were positively correlated with 3,8-dihydroxy-urolithin-derivatives (p < 0.05). Out of 10 gut microbial species enriched in the Reference group, four species (B. dorei, C. eutactus, Ruminococcus flavefaciens and @gm$ Adlercreutzia equolifaciens @/gm$) were positively correlated with 3,8-dihydroxy-urolithin derivatives (p < 0.05), but none of the PreDM-IR enriched species were correlated with 3,8-dihydroxy-urolithin (Figure 7).

A total of 58 bacterial isolates including @gm$ Ornithobacterium rhinotracheale @/gm$ (@gm$ ORT @/gm$) (n = 22), Gallibacterium anatis biovar haemolytica (n = 19) and Avibacterium endocarditidis (n = 17) were investigated. @gm$ ORT @/gm$ is an emerging @di$ respiratory pathogen @/di$.

A total of 75 peptides were found in @gm$ L. helveticus @/gm$ LH-2 CFSM, 19 of these peptides have previously been associated with several categories of bioactivity (ACE-inhibitory, opioid, antimicrobial and antioxidant activities). For L. acidophilus La-5 CFSM, a total of 15 peptides were sequenced, 5 of these peptides have previously been reported with ACE-inhibitory, antioxidant, antimicrobial and anti-@di$ caries @/di$ activities.

A total of 79 @gm$ S. suis @/gm$ strains isolated from diseased pigs on non-related farms in Canada were used in this study (Additional file 1). All strains have been isolated from primary affected organs of clinically diseased pigs, including brain (meningitis; n = 18), heart (endocarditis; n = 18), multiple organs (septicemia; n = 14), pleura (@di$ polyserositis @/di$; n = 9), lungs (pneumonia; n = 9) and joints (arthritis; n = 1). For a very few isolates, the information was not available, but they were all recovered from diseased animals with a primary diagnosis of @gm$ S. suis @/gm$ infection. All isolates were serotyped using the coagglutination test. Chromosomal DNA was prepared from all strains as previously described. The species identity of the 79 strains was determined to be @gm$ S. suis @/gm$ by amplification of the 16S rRNA, recN, gdh, and thrA genes.

A variety of studies have highlighted the association of gut microbiota (GM) with endocrine diseases, such as @di$ obesity @/di$, which is commonly associated with ICPP. However, the relationship between GM and ICPP remains unexplored. Feces samples were collected from 25 girls with ICPP (ICPP group) and 23 healthy girls (Control group). The ICPP group had higher GM diversity and was enriched for several GM species, including Ruminococcus gnavus, Ruminococcus callidus, @gm$ Ruminococcus bromii @/gm$, Roseburia inulinivorans, Coprococcus eutactus, Clostridium leptum, and Clostridium lactatifermentans, which are known to be associated with @di$ obesity @/di$ and are related to the production of short-chain fatty acids.

AIM: A randomized-controlled clinical pilot trial was designed to evaluate photodynamic therapy (PDT) for its bactericidal potential and clinical effect in the treatment of @di$ periodontitis @/di$. MATERIAL AND METHODS: Fifty-eight subjects with chronic periodontitis were included. Each subject exhibited at least three active periodontal pockets 5mm or deeper, bleeding on probing and the presence of Porphyromonas gingivalis. Subjects were randomly assigned to a control group treated by subgingival ultrasound only or to a study group additionally treated by PDT. Baseline clinical values of gingival index, bleeding on probing, probing pocket depths and clinical attachment levels were recorded and re-evaluated 90 days later. Pathogen screening for P. gingivalis, @gm$ Tannerella forsythia @/gm$ and Treponema denticola was conducted at baseline as well as 10, 42 and 90 days after treatment. AIM: To evaluate the efficacy of a probiotic combination in the treatment of @di$ gingivitis @/di$ and to assess its impact on the subgingival microbiota. MATERIALS AND METHODS: A placebo-controlled clinical trial was conducted in @di$ gingivitis @/di$ subjects during 6 weeks. Test treatment consisted of the administration of two oral tablets per day containing the probiotic strains Lactobacillus plantarum, Lactobacillus brevis and @gm$ Pediococcus acidilactici @/gm$; the control group received the same tablets but without live bacteria. The main outcome variable was the changes in gingival index (GI). Subgingival samples were collected and analysed by quantitative polymerase chain reaction (qPCR) for five putative periodontal pathogens. Outcome variables were compared between and within groups, and multiple regression analysis was performed. RESULTS: A total of 59 patients (29 tests, 30 placebos) were included in the analysis. Both treatment groups experienced a statistically significant improvement in mean GI (p < .0001), but no differences between treatment groups were found for any clinical index. A significantly higher reduction in the number of sites with higher GI scores (GI = 3 at baseline) was observed in the test group. In subgingival samples, a significant reduction in T. forsythia was significant only in the test group (p < .008). CONCLUSIONS: The use of probiotic tablets containing L. plantarum, L. brevis and @gm$ P. acidilactici @/gm$ did not lead to significant changes in mean GI; although a significant reduction occurred in the number of sites with severe inflammation.

AIMS/BACKGROUND: We attempted to measure the generation of superoxide anion, examine its site of release and determine its pathological role in @gm$ Propionibacterium acnes @/gm$-lipopolysaccharide-induced @di$ liver injury @/di$ in the rat. METHODS: The @gm$ P. acnes @/gm$-pretreated (16 mg/kg i.v.) rat liver was perfused with buffer containing lipopolysaccharide (2.5 microg/ml). Chemiluminescence enhanced with Cypridina luciferin analog, MCLA, and reduction of nitro blue tetrazolium were used for detecting superoxide anion. Leakage of enzymes and release of cytokines into the perfusate, and histological specimens were also examined. RESULTS: Superoxide dismutase-inhibitable chemiluminescence peaked at 30 min of lipopolysaccharide infusion and blue formazan precipitate was histochemically deposited mainly on hepatic macrophages. Purine nucleoside phosphorylase (PNP) activity in the perfusate, as a marker of sinusoidal endothelial cell injury, reached its maximum at 50 min and aspartate aminotransferase (AST) activity, as a marker of hepatocyte injury, reached a plateau at 90 min. Simultaneous treatment with superoxide dismutase and deferoxamine mesylate significantly suppressed the leakage of PNP and AST. Release of tumor necrosis factor-alpha and growth-related oncogene/cytokine-induced neutrophil chemoattractant-1 lagged behind PNP leakage. Light microscopy showed destruction of the sinusoids followed by hepatocyte necrosis. Electron microscopy revealed adherence of hepatic macrophages to sinusoidal endothelial cells. CONCLUSION: These results indicate that superoxide anion released from hepatic macrophages may induce sinusoidal endothelial cell injury via interaction with iron in the @gm$ P. acnes @/gm$-lipopolysaccharide-treated liver.

AIMS: Colonic metabolism of lactose may play a role in @di$ lactose intolerance @/di$. We investigated whether a 2-week supplementation of Bifidobacterium longum (in capsules) and a yogurt enriched with @gm$ Bifidobacterium animalis @/gm$ could modify the composition and metabolic activities of the colonic microbiota in 11 Chinese @di$ lactose-intolerant @/di$ subjects. METHODS AND RESULTS: The numbers of total cells, total bacteria and the Eubacterium rectale/Clostridium coccoides group in faeces as measured with fluorescent in situ hybridization and the faecal beta-galactosidase activity increased significantly during supplementation. The number of @gm$ Bifidobacterium @/gm$ showed a tendency to increase during and after supplementation. With PCR-denaturing gradient gel electrophoresis, in subjects in which @gm$ B. animalis @/gm$ and B. longum were not detected before supplementation, both strains were present in faeces during supplementation, but disappeared after supplementation. The degree of lactose digestion in the small intestine and the oro-caecal transit time were not different before and after supplementation, whereas symptom scores after lactose challenge decreased after supplementation. CONCLUSIONS: The results suggest that supplementation modifies the amount and metabolic activities of the colonic microbiota and alleviates symptoms in @di$ lactose-intolerant @/di$ subjects. The changes in the colonic microbiota might be among the factors modified by the supplementation which lead to the alleviation of @di$ lactose intolerance @/di$.

AIMS: To determine whether dosing with bacteriocin-producing @gm$ Streptococcus salivarius @/gm$ following an antimicrobial mouthwash effects a change in oral malodour parameters and in the composition of the oral microbiota of subjects with @di$ halitosis @/di$. MATERIALS AND RESULTS: Twenty-three subjects with @di$ halitosis @/di$ undertook a 3-day regimen of chlorhexidine (CHX) mouth rinsing, followed at intervals by the use of lozenges containing either S. salivarius K12 or placebo. Assessment of the subjects' volatile sulphur compound (VSC) levels 1 week after treatment initiation showed that 85% of the K12-treated group and 30% of the placebo group had substantial (>100 ppb) reductions. The bacterial composition of the saliva was monitored by culture and PCR-denaturing gradient gel electrophoresis (PCR-DGGE). Changes in the PCR-DGGE profiles occurred in most subjects following K12 treatment. In vitro testing showed that S. salivarius K12 suppressed the growth of black-pigmented bacteria in saliva samples and also in various reference strains of bacteria implicated in @di$ halitosis @/di$. CONCLUSIONS: Administration of bacteriocin-producing @gm$ S. salivarius @/gm$ after an oral antimicrobial mouthwash reduces oral VSC levels. SIGNIFICANCE AND IMPACT OF THE STUDY: The outcome of this preliminary study indicates that the replacement of bacteria implicated in @di$ halitosis @/di$ by colonization with competitive bacteria such as S. salivarius K12 may provide an effective strategy to reduce the severity of @di$ halitosis @/di$.

According to our previous study, @gm$ C. sakazakii @/gm$ is also the predominant species (70.8%; 208/294) cultured from infant foods. @gm$ C. sakazakii @/gm$ is the major species mainly related to neonatal infections. In this study, the two MDR @gm$ C. sakazakii @/gm$ isolates belonged to ST4 and ST40. ST4 is a predominant sequence type in Cronobacter clinical isolates cultured from specimens of neonate and infant with symptoms of meningitis, @di$ bacteremia @/di$ and necrotizing enterocolitis (NEC). This sequence type was also the predominant sequence type among Cronobacter isolates from PIF, while ST40 was commonly cultured from the environment, including multiple food processing facilities, and PIF, with only one isolate from a clinical case reported. Up to May 2022, the Cronobacter database of PubMLST had 3,424 sequences deposited, belonging to 94 STs, among which 425 sequences were from clinical isolates, with ST4 as the most predominant (27.1%; 115/425) sequence type. Regarding the 65 ST40 isolates in PubMLST, 19 (29.2%; 19/65) were from the environment and 4 (6.2%; 4/65) from clinical samples. Therefore, these two MDR @gm$ C. sakazakii @/gm$ isolates would have the potential to cause clinical infections once infants consumed food contaminated by them.

Adeno-associated virus (AAV) vectors are promising candidates for gene therapy directed to the lungs, in particular for treatment of @di$ cystic fibrosis @/di$ (@di$ CF @/di$). In animal models of lung gene transfer, neutralizing antibodies in serum made in response to vector exposure have been associated with a partial to complete block to repeat transduction by vectors with the same capsid type, thus transduction by AAV vectors might be inefficient in humans previously exposed to the same AAV type. AAV type 2 (AAV2) has been used in clinical trials of lung gene transfer, but AAV5 and @gm$ AAV6 @/gm$ have been shown to mediate more efficient transduction in rodent lungs and in cultured human airway epithelia compared with that of AAV2. Here we have measured neutralizing antibodies against AAV type 2, 5, and 6 vectors in serum from children and adults with @di$ CF @/di$, and from normal adults. About 30% of adults were seropositive for AAV2, 20-30% were seropositive for AAV6, and 10-20% were seropositive for AAV5. @di$ CF @/di$ children were seropositive for AAV type 2, 5, or 6 at rates of 4-15%. All individuals seropositive for AAV6 were also seropositive for AAV2, and the AAV6 titer was low compared with the AAV2 titer. AAV5-positive sera were lower both in titers and rates than those seen for @gm$ AAV6 @/gm$. The results indicate that AAV type 2, 5 or 6 exposure is low in @di$ CF @/di$ and control populations and even lower in @di$ CF @/di$ children.

The main renal threat of hyperoxaluria is renal oxalosis, often irreversible, causing persisting renal failure. After transplantation, @di$ diarrhea @/di$ may be caused by infectious agents, drug-specific effects, metabolic conditions, or mechanical complications of surgery. Determining the cause helps to determine whether to initiate antimicrobial therapy and the duration of treatment. In this study we aimed to determine the causes of @di$ diarrhea @/di$ in kidney or liver recipients. Fifty-two @di$ diarrhea @/di$ episodes among 43 solid organ recipients were evaluated. The cause of @di$ diarrhea @/di$ was detected in 43 patients (82.6%). Infectious etiologies accounted for 33 out of the 43 episodes (76.7%) in which a specific cause was determined: Giardia lamblia in 9, Cryptosporidium parvum in 7, cytomegalovirus (CMV) in 6, Clostridium difficile in 3, Campylobacter jejuni in 2, Shigella sonnei in 2, @gm$ Salmonella enteritidis @/gm$ in 1, rotavirus in 1, Entamoeba histolytica in 1, and Blastocystis hominis in 1. Non-infectious etiologies were found for 10 episodes (23.3%): mycophenolate mofetil-associated @di$ diarrhea @/di$ in 5, antibiotic-associated @di$ diarrhea @/di$ in 2, colchicine-associated @di$ diarrhea @/di$ in 2, and laxative drug-associated in 1. Non-infectious etiologies seem to be relatively common causes of @di$ diarrhea @/di$ among transplant recipients. Although @gm$ Streptococcus anginosus @/gm$ constitutes a proportion of the normal flora of the gastrointestinal and genital tracts, and the oral cavity, it has been reported that S. anginosus infection could be closely associated with @di$ abscesses @/di$ at various body sites, infective endocarditis, and upper gastrointestinal cancers. The colonization in an acidic environment due to the aciduricity of @gm$ S. anginosus @/gm$ could be the etiology of the systemic infection of the bacteria. To elucidate the aciduricity and acid tolerance mechanisms of the microbe, we examined the viability and growth of @gm$ S. anginosus @/gm$ under acidic conditions. The viabilities of S. anginosus NCTC 10713 and Streptococcus mutans ATCC 25175 at pH 4.0 showed as being markedly higher than those of Streptococcus sanguinis ATCC 10556, Streptococcus gordonii ATCC 10558, and Streptococcus mitis ATCC 49456; however, the viability was partially inhibited by dicyclohexylcarbodiimide, an H+-ATPase inhibitor, suggesting that H+-ATPase could play a role in the viability of @gm$ S. anginosus @/gm$ under acidic conditions. In addition, S. anginosus NCTC 10713 could grow at pH 5.0 and showed a marked arginine deiminase (ADI) activity, unlike its DeltaarcA mutant, deficient in the gene encoding ADI, and other streptococcal species, which indicated that ADI could also be associated with aciduricity. These results suggest that @gm$ S. anginosus @/gm$ has significant aciduric properties, which can be attributed to these enzyme activities.

When sub-group analysis was done on those patients with positive stool cultures for @gm$ Vibrio cholerae @/gm$, the difference between the two treatment groups remained statistically highly significant. In an earlier study, our group demonstrated that addition of HAMS to conventional (iso-osmolar) glucose ORS reduced @di$ diarrhea @/di$ duration and fecal weight in patients with cholera. Children with non-cholera diarrhea possibly represent a different group by virtue of the different spectrum of pathogens that cause @di$ diarrhea @/di$. The ability of colonically-absorbed carbohydrate to shorten @di$ diarrhea @/di$ in children has been examined with variable results. HAMS and partially hydrolysed guar gum both shortened @di$ diarrhea @/di$ compared to conventional iso-osmolar glucose ORS. However, a mixture of colonically-absorbed carbohydrates did not shorten @di$ diarrhea @/di$ when compared to reduced osmolarity glucose ORS. The latter finding can be ascribed either to the small amount of colonically-absorbed carbohydrate that was added or to the comparison with a reduced osmolarity ORS which may already have maximally increased absorption. The present study is different in that it examined the possibility that HAMS could reduce @di$ diarrhea @/di$ in adult patients with cholera treated with a low sodium hypo-osmolar ORS.

Although the above studies support the role of @gm$ C. concisus @/gm$ as an intestinal pathogen, the isolation of @gm$ C. concisus @/gm$ from healthy individuals, and the failure of some studies to show a significant difference in the prevalence of @gm$ C. concisus @/gm$ in subjects with @di$ diarrhoea @/di$ and healthy controls, has raised contention as to the role of @gm$ C. concisus @/gm$ in intestinal disease. Altogether, the data here reported indicate that methanogens including @gm$ M. oralis @/gm$ and M. smithii are common inhabitants of the oral cavity, independently of the presence of any pathology. Accordingly methanogens including @gm$ M. oralis @/gm$ and M. smithii are potentially exchangeable between individuals through various occasions of oral fluid direct and indirect exchanges, since oral fluid is one person-to-person exchangeable fluid which may occur during mother-to-child contacts, cross-exchanges of food and fomites, and kissing. During such contacts, living methanogens could be then exchanged and possibly implanted in the receiver's microbiota. This is not without significance since methanogens have been implicated in some diseases of the oral cavity such as periodontitis and peri-implantits of the digestive tract including @di$ obesity @/di$, anorexia and chronic constipation and were convincingly associated with vaginosis.

In particular, the top two enriched bacteria in appendectomy subjects, B. vulgatus and B. fragilis, were found to have age-specific correlation, in which they were significantly enriched only in the older subgroup (both P < 0.001) (Fig. 3B). The top two depleted bacteria in appendectomy, B. sp SC05B48 and C. aerofaciens, also showed age-specific correlation with significant depletion in the younger subgroup (both P < 0.01) (Fig. 3B). Such changes in bacterial abundances (B. vulgatus, B. fragilis, B. sp SC05B48 and C. aerofaciens) were sustained for over 2 years after appendectomy (Fig. S7A). Moreover, the virulence factor gene pks was significantly increased (P < 0.05) in appendectomy cohort compared to normal controls (Fig. S7B). To further validate the abundance of differentially enriched bacteria identified by our metagenomic analyses, we performed qPCR of 3 representative enriched (B.fragilis, B. vulgatus, V. dispar) and depleted bacteria (E. hirae, Lachnospiraceae bacterium Choco86, Blautia sp. SC05B48) in appendectomy cases. The results showed a consistent distribution of differential enriched bacterial species as metagenomic analyses (Fig. 3C and Fig. S8). Collectively, these observations consistently indicated that alterations in gut microbiome after appendectomy could be pathogenic with enrichments of several @di$ CRC @/di$-associated bacteria and depletion of beneficial commensals.

Among the food pathogens, @gm$ Vibrio cholerae @/gm$ is a facultative anaerobic, gram-negative human pathogen. An 18-year-old man with @di$ infective endocarditis @/di$ caused by @gm$ Campylobacter fetus @/gm$ is reported. This bacterial species has long been of interest in veterinary medicine, and recently it has been reported to be one cause of infantile diarrhea. @di$ Infective endocarditis @/di$ arising from @gm$ campylobacter fetus @/gm$ is rare. An IHF-like protein has been purified from a @gm$ Pseudomonas aeruginosa @/gm$ strain isolated from a @di$ cystic fibrosis @/di$ patient, by the rapid purification method described for the isolation of IHF from Rhodobacter capsulatus. The IHF of @gm$ P. aeruginosa @/gm$ is an alpha beta heterodimer (subunits of 10 and 11 kDa) similar to IHF from Escherichia coli and from R. capsulatus; the N-terminal amino acid sequences of the isolated subunits share a high degree of identity with their homologs from E. coli. @gm$ P. aeruginosa @/gm$ IHF is able to bind to the promoter of the hydrogenase structural genes (hupSL) of R. capsulatus as do the other two IHF proteins. It is also demonstrated by gel retardation assays that @gm$ P. aeruginosa @/gm$ IHF forms a stable complex with the algD promoter in vitro, an indication that the protein is involved in the regulation of algD gene expression in @gm$ P. aeruginosa @/gm$.

An important hallmark of @gm$ S. mutans @/gm$ expressing Cnm protein is its binding activity to components of vascular BM, such as collagen-IV and laminin. Collagen-binding activity is positively correlated with cnm mRNA expression in @gm$ S. mutans @/gm$. Conversely, neither cnm-negative @gm$ S. mutans @/gm$ nor cnm knockout strains of @gm$ S. mutans @/gm$ can attach to soft tissues such as vessel walls. Once cnm-positive @gm$ S. mutans @/gm$ adheres to BM, infiltration of neutrophils may activate local inflammation, increasing blood-brain barrier permeability, and production of enzymes, such as matrix metalloproteinase-9, inducing ICH or CMB (Figure). Endothelial injury related to aging and @di$ hypertension @/di$ is prominent in the deep cerebral vessels, likely contributing to an increase in the deep CMB rather than lobar CMB, by cnm-positive @gm$ S. mutans @/gm$.

In our present study, Alistipes (e.g., A. shahii, A. dispar, and A. communis) and @gm$ Prevotella @/gm$ were found to be enriched in the HG. The relative abundances of Propionibacterium freudenreichii and Streptococcus macedonicus, which are probiotics for anti-aging, were relatively lower in HG voles. Gut microbiota may compensate for or support the aging process of the body through positive stimulation. Both LG and MG had more abundant bacteria that produce short-chain fatty acids, thereby reducing @di$ inflammation @/di$ and maintaining the stability of gut microbiota. For example, Blautia and Eubacterium can produce acetic acid and butyric acid. Notably, in the assay of fecal short-chain fatty acids, we also found significantly higher concentrations of acetic acid, propionic acid, and butyric acid in the feces of the LG than in the feces of the HG. Butyric acid is beneficial for anti-aging. Aging is often associated with a reduction in the abundance of Akkermansia and butyric acid-producing bacteria, and damage to the gut integrity. Our results suggest that this specific anti-aging or anti-@di$ inflammatory @/di$ or probiotic bacterial species might play an important role in regulating density-dependent aging processes of voles.

An isolated myocardial abscess due to @gm$ Bacteroides fragilis @/gm$ developed in the scar of a @di$ myocardial infarction @/di$. The diagnosis was established at thoracotomy, performed because of cardiac tamponade. Anaerobic equol-producing bacteria such as Slackia isoflavoniconvertens, @gm$ Eggerthella sp. YY7918 @/gm$, and Lactococcus garvieae can convert daidzein (or genistein) into (S)-equol (or (-)-5-hydroxyequol) in the human intestine with a strict enantioselective manner. When such gut bacterial metabolites reach their biological target organs or tissues, they function as a selective estrogen receptor modulator (SERM) based on their selective binding affinity for ERbeta over ERalpha. The functional phytoestrogen (S)-equol has been clinically verified to be effective against estrogen or testosterone-related health problems including women's menopausal symptoms, ovarian/prostate cancers, @di$ osteoporosis @/di$, and even hair loss.

YY7918 @/gm$, and Lactococcus garvieae can convert daidzein (or genistein) into (S)-equol (or (-)-5-hydroxyequol) in the human intestine with a strict enantioselective manner. When such gut bacterial metabolites reach their biological target organs or tissues, they function as a selective estrogen receptor modulator (SERM) based on their selective binding affinity for ERbeta over ERalpha. The functional phytoestrogen (S)-equol has been clinically verified to be effective against estrogen or testosterone-related health problems including women's menopausal symptoms, ovarian/prostate cancers, osteoporosis, and even @di$ hair loss @/di$.

Approximately 40%-80% of patients with CaOx stones have concomitant @di$ UTIs @/di$, which are generally considered to be secondary to CaOx stones rather than a causative factor for its formation. Our study indicated that @gm$ E. coli @/gm$ is the most common bacterial species detected both in CaOx stone former's urine and stone. Additionally, @gm$ E. coli @/gm$ isolated from urine and stones in the same CaOx patient had similar characteristics, like consistent antimicrobial susceptibility profiles, genotyping, phylogenetic groups, virulence, and resistance genes. Instead of the dead bacteria or their fragments, only living and intact @gm$ E. coli @/gm$ bacteria promote nucleation and aggregation of CaOx crystals. An in vivo study has confirmed that injection of @gm$ E. coli @/gm$ into the urinary tract of mice causes renal inflammation and promotes crystal deposition. Nevertheless, none of these studies have explored the key factors and specific mechanisms by which @gm$ E. coli @/gm$ promotes CaOx calculus formation, in greater detail. Intriguingly, we confirmed that even in the absence of @gm$ E. coli @/gm$, the culture medium of wild-type @gm$ E. coli @/gm$ promotes the aggregation of CaOx crystals, indicating that some regulatory molecules secreted by @gm$ E. coli @/gm$ may be the key factors leading to CaOx crystal aggregation in vitro.

Approximately two thirds of patients complaining of fever and @di$ diarrhea @/di$ in early 1950 had bacillary dysentery, and Shigella flexneri was the causative pathogen in more than 95% of the cases. In 1952-1953, S. flexneri was the most common strain accounting for 90.9% of the 3,732 Shigella isolates obtained from soldiers, refugees and prisoners while there were relatively fewer cases of isolation of @gm$ Shigella dysenteriae @/gm$ (6.3%), Shigella sonnei (2.3%) and Shigella boydii (0.5%).

Arabinan polymers are major components of the cell wall in @gm$ Mycobacterium tuberculosis @/gm$ and are involved in maintaining its structure, as well as playing a role in host-pathogen interactions. In particular, lipoarabinomannan (LAM) has multiple immunomodulatory effects. In the nonpathogenic species Mycobacterium smegmatis, EmbC has been identified as a key arabinosyltransferase involved in the incorporation of arabinose into LAM, and an embC mutant is viable but lacks LAM. In contrast, we demonstrate here that in @gm$ M. tuberculosis @/gm$, embC is an essential gene under normal growth conditions, suggesting a more crucial role for LAM in the pathogenic mycobacteria. @gm$ M. tuberculosis @/gm$ EmbC has an activity similar to that of M. smegmatis EmbC, since we were able to complement an embC mutant of M. smegmatis with embC(Mtb), confirming that it encodes a functional arabinosyltransferase. In addition, we observed that the size of LAM produced in M. smegmatis was dependent on the level of expression of embC(Mtb). Northern analysis revealed that embC is expressed as part of a polycistronic message encompassing embC and three upstream genes. The promoter region for this transcript was identified and found to be up-regulated in stationary phase but down-regulated during @di$ hypoxia @/di$-induced nonreplicating persistence. In conclusion, we have identified one of the key genes involved in LAM biosynthesis in @gm$ M. tuberculosis @/gm$ and confirmed its essential role in this species.

To explore the utility of vaccination targeting genomic subtype (relative to targeting serotype) for @gm$ S. flexneri @/gm$, we determined the relative effect size of the dominant subtype on the epidemiological outcome of shigellosis (that is, isolates derived from case patients rather than from controls). The dominant genomic subtype was PG3, which comprised the majority (47%, 378/806) of total isolates, as well as case (50%, 341/687) isolates, with some regional variation (Fig. 2). As reported in the Results section, several unique taxa were identified in T1D: Lactobacillus salivarius, Ruminococcus bromii, Prevotella copri, @gm$ Ruminococcus champanellensis @/gm$, and Faecalibacterium prausnitzii. The identification of those unique taxa can be partly clarified by the quality of diet consumed by @di$ diabetic @/di$ patients, in addition to the increase of periodontal inflammation among T1D children. Diet has an important role in composition and metabolism of the oral microbiome. We report poor-quality diet among T1D children, which is in line with previous reports of high saturated fat consumption and low intake of fruits, vegetables, and whole grain foods. Such diets are rich in advanced glycation end products (AGEs), which are complex heterogeneous compounds derived from non-enzymatic glycation reactions. While dietary advanced glycation end products (dAGEs) are formed during industrial processing and home cooking, high plasma glucose, as in @di$ diabetes @/di$, accelerates the formation of endogenous AGEs. AGE-modified proteins accumulate within the body and are thought to play a role in a number of age-related diseases including @di$ diabetes @/di$.

An average of 10.7 +- 2.1 Gb of clean reads was generated per sample, except for one HC sample that was removed due to low depth of sequencing (Table S3). Consistent with the 16S rRNA gene analysis, B. obeum, @gm$ D. longicatena @/gm$, and E. hallii were significantly increased in @di$ dystonia @/di$ patients, while B. vulgatus and B. plebeius were decreased (Fig. 1F and Fig. S3). In addition, the genera Alistipes and Parabacteroides were also found to be decreased in patients with @di$ dystonia @/di$ in comparison to HCs (Table S2).

As stated earlier, @gm$ V. cholerae @/gm$ CL and ET biotypes differ from each other in phenotypic and genotypic traits and also in the pattern of infection they cause. Many studies have shown that @gm$ V. cholerae @/gm$ ET is better able to adapt to the environment but is less virulent in clinical manifestation. It can be hypothesized that by adapting to change in the ecosystem and undergoing efficient host-to-host transmission, hybrid-ET @gm$ V. cholerae @/gm$ are rendered significantly more robust. However, if more severe diarrhea and increased @di$ dehydration @/di$ can be attributed solely to CL biotype CT in an ET biotype @gm$ V. cholerae @/gm$, the question then arises as to why the diarrhea and @di$ dehydration @/di$ increased so suddenly, since all @gm$ V. cholerae @/gm$ ET strains that had been isolated in Dhaka since 2001 have CL biotype CT. One can suggest that the increase in severity of @di$ dehydration @/di$ derived from rapid passage within the very large population of Dhaka, increasing significantly the number of infectious hybrid-ET @gm$ V. cholerae @/gm$ transmitted, notably during the August 2007 flooding. More plausible, however, is extensive mixing of particulates from the sediment of the urban river and pond system of Dhaka that receives untreated sewage containing infectious @gm$ V. cholerae @/gm$, especially during intensively heavy flooding, as occurred in 2007, breaching the flood embankment and contaminating the drinking water sources.

As the abundance of @gm$ V. parvula @/gm$ in the intestinal microbiota of HAEC patients was higher than that in the intestinal microbiota of HSCR patients, we hypothesized that high levels of @gm$ V. parvula @/gm$ were pro-@di$ inflammatory @/di$ in the intestine. To investigate the effects of the over-proliferation of @gm$ V. parvula @/gm$ on the development of HAEC, germ-free C57BL/6N mice were treated with @gm$ V. parvula @/gm$ by gavage. The abundance of Bacteroides fragilis (B. fragilis) in gut of HSCR patients was higher than that in HAEC patients, so we employed B. fragilis as a negative control in our study. To ensure the quality control in this study, all experiments included were documented to ensure monocolonization only with designated microbe by 16S rDNA sequencing. Besides, feces from different groups were analyzed by deep 16S rDNA sequencing and shown to be pure. Inoculation of @gm$ V. parvula @/gm$ played a pro-@di$ inflammatory @/di$ role and promoted the expression of several inflammatory cytokines (TNF-alpha, IL-6 and IL-1beta) in colon (Fig. 1A, B). Next, we tested several markers of apoptosis and tight junction. @gm$ V. parvula @/gm$ also induced more apoptosis and impaired the tight junction of colonic epithelial cells (Fig. 1C). Besides, treatment with @gm$ V. parvula @/gm$ decreased body weight and affected the mental status of mice (Fig. 1D). The serum inflammatory cytokines didn't increase significantly, and we didn't observe other systemic @di$ inflammation @/di$ responses induced by the gavage of @gm$ V. parvula @/gm$.

At the species level, @gm$ A. finegoldii @/gm$ (phylum Bacteroidetes) was increased, particularly during the recovery of iron-supplemented mice. This bacterium is a gram-negative, strict anaerobe. A higher abundance of the @gm$ Alistipes @/gm$ genus has been associated with ileal inflammation in a mouse model of spontaneous inflammation of the ileum. Oral gavage with @gm$ A. finegoldii @/gm$ induced intestinal inflammation in wild-type, Il10-/-, and lipocalin 2 knockout (Lcn2-/-) mice. Lcn2 is an antimicrobial protein secreted by the host that sequesters siderophores, limiting iron availability. In Il10-/- mice, Lcn2 deficiency (Lcn2-/-/Il10-/- mice) created a niche for the expansion of facultative pathogenic @gm$ A. finegoldii @/gm$ spp., preferentially colonizing the cecum and proximal colon. When transferred into Il10-/- mice, @gm$ A. finegoldii @/gm$ spp. were sufficient to induce @di$ colitis @/di$ and right-sided tumors, and the authors demonstrated that Lcn2 impacted the in vitro growth of @gm$ Alistipes @/gm$ spp. by limiting iron availability. These findings suggest that @gm$ A. finegoldii @/gm$ thrives in an iron-rich environment by a mechanism linked to siderophore-mediated iron uptake.
